questions.text: In the human body, CO2is formed intracellularly as a byproduct of metabolism. CO2is transported in the bloodstream to the lungs where it is ultimately removed from the body through exhalation. CO2plays various roles in the human body including regulation of blood pH, respiratory drive, and affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen (O2). C02is carried in blood mainly by?
questions.solution:
C02transport occurs in 3 forms :

1.Bicarbonate form (70%)

2. Carbamino compounds (20-25%)

3. Free/dissolved in plasma (5-7%)

questions.text: Smooth muscle cells also develop tonic and phasic contractions in response to changes in load or length. Regardless of the stimulus, smooth muscle cells use cross-bridge cycling between actin and myosin to develop force, and calcium ions (Ca2+) serve to initiate contraction. Smooth muscle contraction due to the release of calcium, occurs because of?

choices.text: Calmodulin dependant myosin light chain kinase

questions.solution:
• Extracellular Ca++ is important for smooth muscle contraction.
  • In Smooth muscles, rise in intracellular [Ca++] leads tobindingof4 Ca++ions with calmodulin.
  • Two mechanisms: Sarcolemmaregulates Ca++ influx and efflux from the extracellular Ca++ pool. TheSarcoplasmic Reticulummembranes determine Ca++ movement between the myoplasm and the SR pool.
  • Calcium-calmodulin complexthenactivatesmyosin light chain kinase(MLCK).
  • MLCK phosphorylates the regulatory light chain of myosin; this phosphorylation then leads to the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Calmodulinisstructurally and functionally related to troponin(smooth muscle lacks troponin).
  • Troponinis present inskeletal musclesand initiates contraction by causing a conformational change in the tropomyosin molecule which then uncovers the active sites on the actin filament.

NOTE:The latch state is thought to reflect a slowing of the cross-bridge cycle, so that the myosin heads remain in contact with the actin filament for a longer time, thereby maintaining tension at a low energy cost. The intracellular [Ca++] falls to a low level during the tonic phase of contraction, though it is still above the resting/ basal [Ca++].

questions.text: The major requirement of cellular energy is met by ATP produced through oxidative phosphorylation which require flow of electrons through ETC to oxygen. Which one of the following is a key component of oxidative phosphorylation?

choices.text: Using NADH and FAD(H2) to accept electrons as substrates are oxidized.
A source of electrons, which is usually oxygen in most tissues
An ATP synthase to synthesize ATP
An ATP synthetase to synthesize ATP

questions.solution:
NAD+and FAD are electron acceptors and NADH and FADH2 are electron donors.

Oxygen is the terminal electron acceptor and is not an electron donor.

The structure of ATP synthase allow the energy of protons moving inside the matrix to be used for ATP synthesis. If protons enter the mitochondria other ways then through the ATP synthase no ATP is generated by the ATP synthase (partial uncoupling). Hence its is the most essential component for ATP synthesis.

Synthetase is an enzyme that uses high-energy phosphate bonds (usually from ATP) to catalyze its reaction, and the ATP synthase creates high energy phosphate bonds and does not use them.

questions.text: The triangles of the neck are topographic areas of the neck bounded by the neck muscles. The carotid triangle is an important division of the anterior set of triangles, with multiple important structures passing through it. It is bounded posteriorly, by:-
questions.solution:
The carotid triangle is posteriorly bounded by anterior border of Sternocleidomastoid muscle.

Boundaries of carotid triangle

  • IN FRONT & ABOVE-Post Belly of Digastric and Stylohyoid Muscle.
  • IN FRONT & BELOW-Superior Belly of Omohyoid.
  • BEHIND-Anterior Border of Sternocleidomastoid.

questions.text: You have joined a gym to improve your health and fitness. During the fitness test, the instructor asks you to stretch first and then bend forward. You know that this is possible since maximum flexion occurs in thoracic vertebra at:-
questions.solution:
• Maximum Thoracic flexion occurs in the lower Thoracic spine because the vertebrae start to orient their facets similar to the Lumbar Spine where the most flexion and extension occurs.
  • Also, the Lower thoracic spine is not as cemented in placeby the floating ribs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ED complaining of chest pain and drooling that started immediately after eating a steak. His past medical history is significant for ingestion of a caustic solution, 5 years ago . On physical examination, the patient can talk normally and breaths without effort. He is drooling. The chest pain is vague and constant. A chest X-ray shows no subcutaneous emphysema. An endoscopy confirms the presence of a retained bolus of meat 25 cm beyond the incisors where a stricture is identified. The bolus is removed and the stricture is dilated. Which of the following anatomic spaces contains the stricture?
questions.solution:
The aortic arch leaves an imprint in the right anterior edge of the oesophagus in the superior mediastinum at about 23 (±3 cm) beyond the upper incisors.
This is the 2nd most common location of injury and stricture formation.

Option 1: The esophagus is compressed by the left main bronchus in the posterior mediastinum. Although this area can also be damaged from caustic ingestions, it resides lower down, at 30 cm beyond the incisors.

Option 3: The anterior mediastinum, limited laterally by the pleura, posteriorly by the pericardium, anteriorly by the sternum, the left transversus thoracis muscle and the fifth, sixth, and seventh left costal cartilages, contains only the superior and inferior sterno-pericardial ligaments andremnants of the thymus. These structures do not come into contact with the esophagus.

Option 4 :The abdominal portion of the esophagus is variable in length (0.5–2.5 cm). The junction of the esophagus and the stomach lies inferior to the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm. The phreno-esophageal ligament anchors the esophagogastric junction to allow movement with respiration but to prevent significant (more than 1–2 cm) proximal movement of the superior margin of the stomach.

questions.text: Pyridoxal phosphate is synthesized from the vitamin pyridoxine (vitamin B6) and acts as a cofactor of various reactions. The reactive aldehyde group of PLP usually is a part of covalent catalysis for these enzymes-catalyzed reactions. PLP is required for the activity of all of the following enzymes except:
questions.solution:
Vitamin B6 is involved in a variety of reactions as shown below:

  • Carbohydrate metabolism: Glycogen Phosphorylase
  • Amino Acid Metabolism: All Transaminases – ALT, AST Cystathionine β synthase ,Cystathioninase, decarboxylases, Kynureninase, Heme synthesis, ALA synthase
  • Lipid metabolism:- Synthesis of arachidonic acid, Synthesis of Sphingosine (Serine palmitoyltransferase & sphingosine-1-phosphate lyase)
  • Steroid Hormone action: Removes hormone receptor complex from DNA & terminates the action of hormone.

Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase requires NADP or vitamin B3 (Niacin) as a coenzyme.

questions.text: Bilirubin and urobilinogen are products of heme catabolism which occur mainly in liver and intestine. This processing is hindered in some disease states causing Hyperbilirubinemia. A condition of Hyperbilirubinemia with the absence of urobilinogen in urine is seen in:

choices.text: Obstruction of the common bile duct

questions.solution:
• Urobilinogen is formed from degradation of bile pigments by bacterial action.
  • In case of obstruction to bile flow,as happens in cholelithiasis or any kind of biliary obstruction, There will be no urobilinogen in urine.
  • So, No formation of stercobilinogen and the patient passes clay colored stools.

Option analysis:

  • Hemolysis produces a lot of urobilinogen which is excreted in urine ??' option a and c are excluded.
  • In hepatocellular jaundice, urobilinogen can be normal or reduced. The question specifically uses the word "absent" ??' options b is also excluded.
Parameter Pre-hepatic Hepatocellular Obstructive
Basic mechanism of raised bilirubin Hemolysis defective uptake, conjugation and excretion of bilirubin by hepatocytes defective excretion of bile due to the obstruction of biliary tract
Type of serum bilirubin raised mainly unconjugated unconjugated + conjugated mainly conjugated (>50%)
Urine bilirubin absent present present
Urine urobilinogen present present absent
Prototype example Hemolytic anaemia viral hepatitis common bile duct stone
Prothrombin time normal abnormal; that is n't corrected by vitamin K inj. abnormal; that is corrected by the vitamin K inj.
Additional features features of hemolysis on peripheral blood smear, reticuloytosis, low Hb, low haptoglobin Marked rise of serum ALT and ALP Marked rise of serum ALP (>3 times)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was ill advised by someone to take higher doses of vitamin E supplementation daily to boost his immunity. Vitamin E being a fat-soluble vitamin can accumulate in the body if higher than recommended doses are taken for prolonged periods. He might show which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin E is believed to be inhibiting protein kinase C–mediated platelet aggregation and nitric oxide production hence leading to bleeding tendencies and elevated bleeding time.
  • In patients with unexplained bruising or bleeding, it is important to review vitamin E supplementation.

Other options:

Option A: Hypercalcemia occurs as a result of Vitamin D toxicity.

Option B:Raised intracranial tension (pseudotumor cerebri) occurs as a result of acute toxicity of vitamin A.

Option D:Thiamine deficiency can result in psychosis.

questions.text: In order to enhance the functional capability of enzymes, the amino acid residues at the active site needs to be identified and changed to know their effect on catalysis. This can be done by using which of the following technique?
questions.solution:
Codon for specific aminoacids can be altered using site-directed mutagenesis.

Site-directed mutagenesis

  • Identification of the specific roles of given aminoacyl residues in substrate binding and catalysis.
  • For eg : A particular aminoacyl residue functions as a general acid can be tested by replacing it with an aminoacyl residue incapable of donating a proton.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has a history of intermittent abdominal pain and episodes of confusion and psychiatric problems. High amounts of δ-aminolevulinate and porphobilinogen is also detected in his urine analysis. The patient also has a mutation in the gene for uroporphyrinogen I synthase (porphobilinogen deaminase). The probable diagnosis of the patient is:
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Acute Intermittent Porphyria.

Acute intermittent porphyria(AIP) is a common form in humans characterized by acute abdominal pain and neurological symptoms There is partial deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD). The porphyrin precursors, porphobilinogen (PBG), and delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) accumulates in the body. The mechanism is given in figure:

questions.text: Blood volume refers to the total amount of fluid circulating within the arteries, capillaries, veins, venules, and chambers of the heart at any time. The components that add volume to blood include red blood cells (erythrocytes), white blood cells (leukocytes), platelets, and plasma. Plasma accounts for about 60% of total blood volume while erythrocytes make up roughly 40% along with leukocytes and platelets. In a person weighing 100 Kgs, what would the blood volume be?
questions.solution:
Blood volume = 8% of body weight. = 8/100× 100kg = 8L

  • The intracellular component of the body water accounts for about 40%of body weight and the extracellular component for about20%.
  • Approximately 25% of the extracellularcomponent is in the vascular system (plasma = 5% of body weight) and 75% outside the blood vessels (interstitial fluid = 15% of body weight).
  • The total blood volume is about 8% of body weight.

questions.text: The membranes of mammalian cells are composed of an ordered array of lipids and proteins, the latter containing carbohydrate residues directed towards the exterior and important in the interaction of cells with each other and with external proteins. In many cases, chemical or functional changes in these membranes are central to the pathogenesis of a disease. All of the following are characteristics of the plasma membrane, except?

choices.text: Serves as a selective transport route through the facilitation of both active and passive transport.
Possesses a thickness of 1 to 2 μm.
Possesses a thickness of 1 to 2 μm.
Serves as a sensor for signals from the extracellular environment.

questions.solution:
• Plasma membrane of eukaryotic cells has a thickness of about 5 nm,constituted by lipid bilayer and embedded proteins. Hence, option B is the answer.
  • It is selective for the transport of substances into or out of the cells → for active as well as passive transports(correct)
  • It consists of Na+-K+pump. It causes active transport of sodium out of the cell and that of potassium into the cell. Thus,ionic gradients are established(correct)
  • Proteins – Integral proteins (sensors for signals from the external environment) andperipheral proteins.

Such questions can be approached by excluding other options.

Note: In 1925, Gorter and Grendel measured the surface area of the lipids they extracted from erythrocyte plasma membranes. They used a device called a Langmuir trough in which the lipids are allowed to line up at an air-water interface.

questions.text: Endopeptidases are a group of hydrolases that catalyze the hydrolysis of peptidic bonds, and thus, hydrolyze proteins. These enzymes are also very chemo-, regio- and enantioselective, which are active under soft reaction conditions (pH 6–8) and are easily handled biocatalysts that do not require the presence of cofactors. They break peptide bonds of nonterminal amino acids (i.e. within the molecule). For this reason, endopeptidases cannot break down peptides into monomers. They are usually very specific for certain amino acids. All are endopeptidases EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic proteases are of two types:
(1)Endopeptidases– They hydrolyze interior peptide bonds of polypeptides and proteins.Trypsin, chymotrypsin, and elastaseare endopeptidases.
(2)Exopeptidases– They hydrolyze external peptide bonds of polypeptides and proteins.Carboxypeptidases A & Bare exopeptidases.

1 Not correct
2 Not correct
3 Content of carotid sheath
4 Not correct

questions.text: Facilitated diffusion(also known as facilitated transporter passive-mediated transport) is the process of spontaneous passive transport (as opposed to active transport) of molecules or ions across a biological membrane via specific transmembrane integral proteins. Molecules and ions move down their concentration gradient reflecting their diffusive nature. Facilitated diffusion is characterized by all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
• Facilitated diffusion is a carrier-mediated transport.
  • ATP is not consumed in this transport so does not require energy (option-3)
  • A conformational change in the carrier molecule causes the substance to be transported to the other side of the membrane.
  • Some models hypothesized for the carrier proteins ~ flip-flop model (transverse diffusion).
  • The rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the Vmax level (option-1).
  • As it is transported through a carrier, it can be competitively inhibited (option-2)
  • Specific carriers available for specific diffusion of substances (option-4)

Saturability, Specificity and inhibition are the characteristics of the Facilitated diffusion

AURICULOTEMPORAL NERVE TRAGUS, CRUS OF HELIX AND ADJOINING AREA OF HELIX

questions.text: Myelin loss can occur as a result of direct damage to the myelin sheath or indirectly through a primarily genetic disorder or attack during inflammation or toxic exposure. In addition, axon degeneration will lead to secondary loss of the myelin sheath (as in Wallerian degeneration). In genetic disease in which there is a failure of normal myelination, the CNS white matter is either hypomyelinated or dysmyelinated. The Myelin in CNS is formed by which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
• Myelin sheathin theCNSis formed by theoligodendrocytes;
  • Myelin sheathof theperipheral nervesis formed by theSchwann cells.
  • One oligodendrocytehelps myelination of approx. 30 neurons but myelinate multiple axons.
  • One Schwann cellhelps myelination of 1 neuron.
  • In CNS - Unmyelinated axons are bare.
  • In PNS - Unmyelinated axons are not bare. They are surrounded by Schwann cell processes.
  1. They do not form a multilayer covering but extend their processes, which surrounds the part of axons.
  2. Schwann cell with its unmyelinated axons - Remak bundle.

questions.text: Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide–gated (HCN) channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4) with HCN4 being widely expressed in the SA node. It has also been dubbed an “f” channel and the current produced as funnycurrent. Which of the following is a function of these channels?
questions.solution:
• HCN channel is a Na+channel (permeable to both Na+and K+ions, with increased permeability to Na+),consists of four either identical or non-identical subunits that are integrally embedded in the cell membranes of SA nodal cells to create an ion-conducting pore.
  • Also referred to as “h” channel(activated followinghyperpolarization) and the current through the h channels is called “h” current (Ih), and because of its unusual (funny) activation, it has also been dubbed an“f” channel and the current produced as funny current.
  • A major contributor to pacemaker potential.
  • It is a type of metabotropic receptor associated channel activated by cyclic nucleotides(cAMP/cGMP) and more the hyperpolarization, more the activation of the channel.
  • HCN channels are encoded by four genes (HCN1,2,3,4) with HCN4 are widely expressed in the SA node.

questions.text: Gene therapy (also called human gene transfer) entails the utilization of the therapeutic delivery of nucleic acids into a patient's cells as a drug to treat disease. Which of the following is the most common gene delivery system for 'In-vivo' gene therapy?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus in gene therapy:

  • ds DNA virus
  • Replication deficient
  • Used in In Vivo approach
  • gene therapy
  • As vaccines
  • For cancer therapy

Advantages:

  • Remain as an episome (extrachromosomal DNA) So doesn’t integrate into the genome. (no chance of insertional mutagenesis)
  • The maximum size of the insert by the adenoviral vector is36kb.
Vectors used for gene delivery :
Viral Vectors Non-viral Vectors
  • Retroviruses
  • Liposomes
  • Adenoviruses
  • Plasmids
  • Herpes simplex viruses
  • Physical methods

questions.solution:
VAGINA HISTOLOGY

  • Mucosal lining: Nonkeratinized Stratified Squamous epithelium
  • Lamina propria: Loose connective tissue
  • Muscle coat ·Fibrous coat: Connective tissue
  • There are NO GLANDS in vaginal mucosa
  • Vaginal fluid is acidic;Due to glycogen- fermentation by Doderlein’s bacilli

questions.text: Imaging reveals a major blockage of right coronary artery near the crux of the heart just proximal to the origin of the posterior interventricular artery. Which part of the heart would be affected by the ischemia that results from this blockage ?

choices.text: Anterior two thirds of the interventricular septum

questions.solution:
The AV nodal artery, which branches from the right coronary artery proximal to the origin of the posterior interventricular artery, usually supplies the AV node.

Option A: The SA node is supplied by the SA nodal artery, a branch of the proximal part of the right coronary artery, or by the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery.

Option C: The left anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two thirdsof the interventricular septum.

Option D: The marginal branch of the right coronary artery supplies most of the right ventricle. Its origin is well proximal to the crux of the heart and would not be affected by this blockage.

Note:
The crux of the heart is the area on the lower back side of the heart where the coronary sulcus (the groove separating the atria from the ventricles) and the posterior interventricular sulcus (the groove separating the left from the right ventricle) meet.

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy was hospitalized following a seizure. He was not eating enough, prior to his hospital admission due to a stomach infection. At admission, his blood glucose was 24 mg/dl (age-referenced normal is 60-100). His urine was negative for ketone bodies, but positive for a variety of dicarboxylic acids. A diagnosis of medium-chain fatty acyl CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is made. In patients with MCAD deficiency, the fasting hypoglycemia is a consequence of:

choices.text: Decreased ability to convert acetyl CoA to glucose
Increased production of ATP and NADH
Increased conversion of acetyl CoA to acetoacetate

questions.solution:
MCAD deficiency results indecreased production of acetyl CoA,due to Impaired oxidation of medium chain fatty acids (<12 C in length).

As acetyl-CoA is an allosteric activator of gluconeogenic enzyme pyruvate carboxylase, hence, glucose levels fall.

MCAD patients havenon-ketotic hypoglycemiaduring starvation due to lack of availability of ketone body substrate acetyl-CoA and dicarboxylic acidosis.

Option A- Acetyl CoA cannot be used for the net synthesis of glucose.

Option C- Acetoacetate is a ketone body, and with MCAD deficiency ketogenesis is decreased. Impaired fatty acid oxidation means thatless ATP and NADH are made(option B), and both are needed for gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents with intractable vomiting and inability to eat or drink for the past 3 days. His blood glucose level is still normal. Which of the following is most important for the maintenance of the blood glucose in this patient:
questions.solution:
Gluconeogenesis occurs in fasting & starvation and occurs mainly in the liver, So the answer is liver

  • Fasting is lack of food for 12-18 hour
  • Starvation is lack of food for 1-3 days or longer
  • Glycogen of liver can maintain blood glucose for 12-18 hours.
  • After that period, liver gluconeogenesis is the main source of blood glucose during fasting/starvation.

The end product of glycogenolysis of glycogen stored in the skeletal muscles is glucose- 6- phosphate and not glucose due to the absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase. Hence muscle glycogen cannot contribute to blood glucose directly.

Figure below shows the role of liver in fed and fasting state under hormonal control.

→ Fed state is mainly related to glycogen metabolism while fasted state shows process related to gluconeogenesis from gluconeogenic substrates.

questions.text: The enteric nervous system (ENS) is a quasi-autonomous part of the nervous system and includes a number of neural circuits that control motor functions, local blood flow, mucosal transport, and secretions, and modulates immune and endocrine functions. Most enteric neurones involved in motor functions are located in the myenteric plexus with some primary afferent neurones located in the submucous plexus. Which of the following motor events is integrated entirely within the Enteric Nervous System?
questions.solution:
Peristalsisis a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen, and it occurs in all parts of the gastrointestinal tract from the esophagus to the rectum, an excellent example of theintegrated activity of the enteric nervous system.

Intesto-intestinal reflex: If an area of the bowel is grossly distended, contractile activity in the rest of the bowel is inhibited. It depends on the extrinsic neural connections with the Enteric Nervous System; sectioning of the extrinsic nerve will abolish this reflex.

Recto-sphincteric reflex: When the rectum is distended by fecal material, the internal anal sphincter relaxes. This reflex will also signal the urge for defecation. (When the rectum is filled to about 25% of its capacity, there is an urge for defecation). If the environmental conditions are not suitable for defecation, then there will be voluntary contraction of the external anal sphincter to overcome the urge for defecation. When it is convenient to defecate, there is voluntary relaxation of the external anal sphincter and evacuation of faeces occurs. First urge to defecate occurs at a rectal pressure of 18 mm Hg.

Gastro-ileal reflex: Shortly after eating food , there is relaxation of the ileo-cecal sphincter and increase in the contractile activity of the ileum. It promotes passage of small intestinal contents into the colon. This reflex is mediated by the extrinsic autonomic nerves to the intestine.

questions.text: A full-term female infant during her neonatal period is not gaining weight and has metabolic acidosis. On physical examination at 6 months, she showed hypotonia, small muscle mass, severe head lag, a persistent acidosis (pH 7.0 to 7.2) with a failure to thrive. The blood examination showed highly elevated levels of lactate, pyruvate, and alanine. Thiamine administration did not alleviate the lactic acidosis. Which of the following enzyme is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
The elevated levels of pyruvate, lactate, and alanine in blood indicate that there is a block in the pathway leading from pyruvate toward the TCA cycle. It shows a most probable deficiency in pyruvate dehydrogenase which can cause a buildup of pyruvate.

Pyruvate has three fates other than conversion to acetyl-CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase:

  1. conversion to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase
  2. reduction to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase
  3. transamination to the amino acid alanine

Thus, on build-up of pyruvate, an increase in lactate and alanine would be expected if pyruvate dehydrogenase was deficient.

questions.text: The hilum is a wedge-shaped area on the medial aspect of each lung, that allows passage of blood vessels and nerves into the lungs and helps anchor the lung roots. The structure passing the most inferior through the right hilum would be:-
questions.solution:
Inferior pulmonary vein is the lowermost structure in the hila of each lung.

Arrangement of structures at the lung hilum (above downwards)
Right side Left side
Eparterial bronchus Pulmonary artery
Pulmonary artery Left principal bronchus
Hyparterial bronchus Inferior pulmonary vein
Inferior pulmonary vein

questions.text: An ionophore is a chemical species that reversibly binds ions. Many ionophores are lipid-soluble entities that transport ions across the cell membrane. Ionophores catalyze ion transport across hydrophobic membranes, such as liquid polymeric membranes (carrier-based ion-selective electrodes) or lipid bilayers found in the living cells or synthetic vesicles (liposomes). All are true of Ionophores, except?
questions.solution:
Ionophores-

  • Large number of antibiotic substances, capable of inducing passage of specific ions across biological membranes.
  • They can be either channel formers or mobile ion carriers and the process is called ionophoresis.E.g. Valinomycin, vancomycin and nigericin.
  • Function as ion shuttles for the movement of ions across membranes by forming a channel or forming a complex with the ion.
  • Form lipid-soluble complexes(Hydrophobic)with specifications, which are carried through the mitochondrial membrane. E.g. valinomycin forms complex with K+ and the complex then readily passes through the membrane (option-3)
  • Metabolic uncouplers (e.g. dinitrophenol) increases the permeability of mitochondria to protons (the mitochondrial membrane is otherwise impermeable to protons).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came in with complaints of increased frequency of urination, especially at night, apart from the sensation of residual urine even after urinating. You order a few tests, and since they turned out to be normal, you make a diagnosis of benign prostatic hyperplasia and plan to give medications for the same. When you give the patient the medicine, you mention that it is a drug that acts on the smooth muscle cells of the prostate, leading to ‘apoptosis.’ Which of the following acts by this mechanism?
questions.solution:
• Induction of apoptosis in prostate smooth muscle cells in BPH is shown by Terazosin and Doxazosin
  • This apoptosis may lessen the symptoms associated with chronic BPH by limiting cell proliferation
  • The apoptotic effect of terazosin and doxazosin appears to be related to the quinazoline moiety rather than 1 receptor antagonism.

*Tamsulosin, a non-quinazoline 1 receptor antagonist, does not produce apoptosis

questions.text: Using a new technique, Hb was estimated in a blood sample. The test was repeated 10 times. The reports were: 9.5, 9.2, 9.4, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5 and 12.1. The accurate value of Hb was estimated by standard tests to be 10.2. The new technique has:
questions.solution:
In the given question,

Mean of 10 Hb values = Sum (9.5, 9.2, 9.4, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5 and 12.1)/10 = 100/10 = 10

  • Validity means getting the right results, whether positive or negative and reliability means getting the same result every time, irrespective of whether it is right or wrong.
  • Since the results obtained by the test are different than the actual value of Hb, it is not valid or accurate.
  • Also, since every time we are getting different values, the test is not reliable.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male came into your clinic with a complaint of a sore throat. You diagnose it as a case of acute pharyngitis and prescribe a combination medication of amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, twice a day for 5 days. The maintenance rate of drugs is primarily dependent on:-
questions.solution:
Maintenance dose rate = Clearance × Target Plasma concentration
  • Maintenance dose depends on clearance and target plasma concentration

With respect to this case, since targeted plasma concentration is not mentioned, clearance is the answer. Amoxicillin and beta-lactams in general, cause time-dependent killing and we tend to maintain a dose above the MIC for the maximum time possible.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of bloody stools. His BP was constantly lowering and he was showing symptoms of shock. The patient gave a history of consumption of pork and raw sausages. Which of the following organism is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical condition is suggestive of Pigbel, caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Clostridium perfringens:

→13 major & minor toxins are present.

  • Type A - E
  • Most infections are caused by Type A/α toxin.

Causes:

  1. Gas gangrene:Pain, crepitus
  2. Food poisoning: due to contaminated meat products. The incubation period is 8-24 hrs.
  3. Pigbel:
  • due to uncooked pork consumption.
  • Causes necrotizing enteritis.
  • due to beta toxin Type C.
  • Characterized by abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, shock, and peritonitis.
  • Severe and often fatal.
  • Also known as “Pigbel” in Papua New Guinea and as “Darmbrand” (meaning “fire bowels”) in Germany.

Reactions of Clostridium perfringens:

  • Nagler's reaction
  • Stormy fermentation in litmus milk
  • Target hemolysis
  • Reverse CAMP test

Answers to other options:

Option 1: Echinococcus (dog tapeworm): causes cystic echinococcosis, also known as hydatid disease.

Option 2: T. saginata (beef tapeworm): Intestinal taeniasis.

Option 4: Clostridium tetani: causes tetanus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant female presented to the hospital with low-grade fever, headache, swollen lymph nodes, and runny nose. On laboratory examination, she was detected positive for rubella infection. The risk of damage to the fetus by maternal rubella is maximum if the mother gets infected in which of the following trimester?
questions.solution: The risk of congenital malformations following infections by teratogenic organisms is maximum in the first trimester, so the best option is 6-12 weeks.

questions.text: The body of a 45-year-old man was brought in for an autopsy. The previous night, the man had got into an argument with another person at a bar over political opinions. The heated argument had turned violent and ended with the other person shooting at the victim with his unlicensed rifle. To avoid being exposed, that person and the bar owner had taken the victim to a doctor who had accepted to remove the bullet and suture the wound in private. The victim had unfortunately succumbed to the injuries in the early hours of this morning. While performing the autopsy, the forensic doctor faced difficulty in determining the entry and exit of the bullet wound. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Kennedy phenomenon:-

  • Iatrogenic surgical alteration or suturing of the entrance wound.
  • The evaluation of whether the wound is entrance or exit becomes difficult.

Cookie-cutter phenomenon:-

  • It is seen from the near shot entry wound of the shotgun.

Formication

  • Patients feel the insects crawling under the skin
  • Seen in Cocaine & ergot

Gordon Phenomenon

  • Prinsloo and Gordon (1951) described artefactual extravasation of blood into the anterior neck structures at autopsy.
  • It may be a source of confusion, resembling traumatic bruises.
  • To eliminate this artifact, bloodless dissection of the neck is recommended in asphyxial deaths

questions.text: After a thorough sweep of the crime scene, the forensic team was able to collect 4 fired bullets. They can now be used for comparison with the bullet recovered from the victim. Among the details recorded for ballistics were also the primary and secondary markings over the metal bullets. What will the forensic team be able to conclude from the above findings?
questions.solution:
*Markings on the bullet are used to identify the gun used.

  • Bullet fingerprinting -Study of comparison of markings on crime bullet & test bullet under a comparison microscope
  • Primary Marking/Class Characteristics:
  • Produced by rifling groovesQ·
  • Primary markings are used to identify the make & model of the guns involved.
  • Secondary markings or individual/accidental characteristics
  • Produced by irregularities by the manufacturing process
  • are different for each gun produced by the same manufacturer.
  • They are useful in identifying the specific gun which was fired.

#Fired cartridge case shows

  • Firing pin marking
  • Extractor markings
  • Ejector marking

#Rifling markings are found only in the fired bullet; not in the fired cartridge case.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female comes into the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing, with no associated cough or fever. On examination, you notice that the RR is elevated, there is significant wheeze bilaterally. You suspect it could be an acute exacerbation of asthma, provide short-acting beta-2 agonists and prescribe inhaled long-acting corticosteroids for daily use, until review. The logic behind giving corticosteroids for asthma is that they:-

choices.text: Decrease mucosal edema by suppressing the inflammatory response

questions.solution:
In patients with Asthma, Corticosteroids are useful as they can decrease mucosal edema by suppressing inflammatory response

Corticosteroids

  • These are potent anti-inflammatory drugs and also decrease bronchial hyperreactivity and mucosal edema.
  • Anti-inflammatory action is due to decreased recruitment of inflammatory cells as well as decreased production of PGs and LTs.
  • These are not bronchodilators but increase the sensitivity to β2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists also increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.
  • Inhaled steroids include beclomethasone, budesonide, mometasone, fluticasone, flunisolide, and triamcinolone. These have very little oral absorption and thus little systemic activity after inhalation (>90% reaches GIT after inhalational route, only 4-5% is retained in lungs).
  • Hoarseness of voice and oropharyngeal candidiasis is very common adverse effects.
  • Candidiasis can be prevented by gargling after each dose and topical nystatin (can be used for treatment also).
  • Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant lady admitted to your hospital delivered a baby today morning. During the first 6 months of the lactation period, Which of the following contraceptives is not advisable?
questions.solution:
• Combined oral contraceptives (COC) are relatively contraindicated in the first six months of delivery, as they decrease breastmilk output.
  • Progestin-only methods can be used after 6 weeks of delivery safely as they have little to no effect on lactation post-six weeks.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female recently delivered a healthy baby to your hospital. She asked for contraceptive advice and the physician recommended her to take a progesterone-only contraceptive pill in her lactating period. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the pill given?
questions.solution:
Progesterone only pills (POPs)

  • Aka lactation/mini/micro pills / intraceptive pills
  • Progestin-only methods act by prevention of ovulation as well as thickening of cervical mucus.
  • They have no direct effect on sperm survival.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient complains of fever and fatigue beginning 15 days ago accompanied by headache, weakness, palpitation, abdominal pain, and diarrhea a week later. On her physical examination, the temperature was 39 degrees C, pulse rate: 92/min, rhythmic, breath rate: 24/min, blood pressure: 100/60 mmHg. Her sclerae were sub icteric, her skin and conjunctivae were pale, her lips and tongue were dry. After microbiological analysis, she was diagnosed with typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi. Which of the following is the best selective media for Salmonella?

choices.text: Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar medium

questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair's brilliant-green bismuth sulphite agar -Bestselective and indicator medium used for the isolation of Salmonella species.

·Bismuth sulphite, brilliant green- inhibitors→ hinder the growth of most bacteria while allowing salmonella to grow.

Ferrous sulphate- Reacts with H2S → formation of ferrous sulfide→brown-black coloration and also diffuses into the surrounding medium, giving a brown–black halo.

Option 1: Thiosulphate citrate bile salt agar(TCBS)is used for Vibrio.

Option 3: Sorbitol MacConkey agar-For EHEC (Enterohaemorrhagic Escherichia coli).

questions.text: A 23-yr-old male athlete who is practising for his upcoming marathon competition next week , felt chest discomfort during his practice which relieved after few minutes of rest. Which of the following is false regarding the cell injury in this scenario?

choices.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
Accumulation of myelin figures in the cytoplasm

questions.solution:
On microscopic examination of reversibly injured cells, small clear vacuoles may be seen within the cytoplasm; these represent distended and pinched-off segments of the ER. This pattern of nonlethal injury is sometimes called hydropic change or vacuolar degeneration.

The ultrastructural changes of reversible cell injury, visible by electron microscopy include the following:

  • Plasma membrane alterations, such as blebbing, blunting, and loss of microvilli
  • Mitochondrial changes,including swelling and the appearance of small amorphous densities
  • Accumulation of “myelin figures” in the cytosol composed of phospholipids derived from damaged cellular membranes
  • Dilation of the ER, with detachment of polysomes
  • Nuclear alterations, with disaggregation of granular and fibrillar elements

Phenomena that consistently characterize irreversible cell injury:

  • inability to reverse mitochondrial dysfunction (lack of oxidative phosphorylation and ATP generation) even after resolution of the original injury
  • profound disturbances in membrane function (breakdown of plasma membrane).

questions.text: A patient with repeated episodes of diarrhea and fever visited the OPD. The doctor sent the patient for stool examination and culture in the microbiology laboratory. In the laboratory, what is the screening procedure used to differentiate Salmonella and Shigella from other Enterobacteriaceae?
questions.solution:
Inability to ferment lactose is used to differentiate Salmonella and Shigella from other Enterobacteriaceae.

Option 1, 3, 4

Enterobacteriaceae properties:

1. Ferments glucose

2. Reduces nitrate to nitrite

3. Oxidase test negative

4. Catalase positive (exceptShigella dysenteriae type-1)

5. Motile,exceptShigella and Klebsiella.

Option 2

Lactose fermenters Non Lactose fermenters

Escherichia

Klebsiella

Enterobacter

Other members of the Enterobacteriaceae family

including Salmonella and Shigella.

questions.text: A 55 years old male accident victim in casualty urgently needs blood. The blood bank is unable to determine his ABO group, as his red cell group and plasma group does not match. Emergency transfusion of the patient should be with:

choices.text: RBC corresponding to his red cell group and colloids/ crystalloid
Whole blood corresponding to his plasma group

questions.solution:
Selection of blood for emergency transfusion

  1. If the patient’s blood group is known, an unmatched blood group of the same group may be used.
  2. If the patient’s blood cannot be determined, Group O red blood cells should be chosen. The use of such unmatched blood should be Rh (–ve) when used in women of child-bearing age in whom we do not want sensitization to Rh antigen.
  3. As Rh-negative blood is often in limited supply, Rh-positive blood is used in the emergency transfusion of older females and males of unknown blood groups. In such cases, sensitization may occur but the risk of an immediate hemolytic reaction is low. O blood group is the universal donor and therefore, should be given to this patient.

questions.text: A patient visited the ophthalmology department as he was experiencing visual disturbances and headaches at work. He is a corporate banker by profession. According to WHO, blindness is defined when there is an inability to count fingers at a distance of?
questions.solution:
• WHO defines blindness as ‘visual acuity of <3/60 better eye with best possible correction’
  • National program for control of blindness India defines Blindness as ‘visual acuity of <3/60 in the better eye with best possible correction’

WHO categories of Visual Impairment:

[MNEMONIC - LESMA]

Low vision <6/18 - 6/60
Economic blindness <6/60 - 3/60 -work vision
Social blindness <3/60 - 1/60 -walk vision
Manifest blindness < 1/60 - Perception of Light +
Absolute blindness Perception of Light -ve, unspecified causes

questions.text: A 29-year-old female with 2 kids presented to the gynecology department in the hospital for Cu-T insertion. The physician inserted Cu-T-380A IUCD in the patient. In how many years should the Cu-T be replaced?
questions.solution:
Cu-T 380A:

  • MC used IUD in India.
  • 380 is the surface area of Cu in mm2 ·
  • A : Arm [Ag - CuT 380 Ag; Au - CuT 380 Au].
  • The effective lifespan of Cu-T 380A IUD is 12 years but approved for 10 years use, and it should be replaced after this time period.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency room with a severe productive cough producing thick bloody sputum resembling a "currant-jelly" like appearance. Culture using MacConkey agar reveals pink colonies, with large mucoid colonies on routine laboratory media. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Klebsiella pneumoniae is most likely responsible for this patient's pneumonia.

  • Patients with K. pneumoniae infections usually have predisposing conditions such as alcoholism, advanced age, chronic respiratory disease, and diabetes.
  • The upper lobes of the lungs are predominantly affected.
  • The "currant-jelly" sputum distinguishes K. pneumoniae fromthe other organisms.
  • K. pneumoniae is Lactose fermenting (pink colonies on MacConkey agar) and due to its thick capsule, the colonies have a mucoid appearance (Refer to the image below).

questions.text: A 10 year old boy, with normal growth and development came to the OPD with a 14 day history of continuous involuntary jerky movements of the left half of body, including the head. The patient was completely unvaccinated as informed by his mother. EEG revealed generalized slowing. Brain magnetic resonance imaging showed focal T2 hyperintensity in the right parasagittal cortex. The given condition is a complication of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
Measles:

  • Cause: RNA paramyxovirus. ·Incubation period: 10-14 days.
  • Source of infection: Cases [No carriers, no ice-berg phenomenon].
  • Mode of transmission: Respiratory/air droplets.
  • Period of communicability: 4 days before & 5 days after the rash.
  • Pathognomic clinical feature: Koplik spot [opposite to lower 2nd molar].
  • Clinical feature: Retro-auricular origin of rash.
  • MC complication: Serous otitis media.

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare, late complication of measles- Aka ‘Dawson's disease’, Dawson’s encephalitis.

  • Vaccine: Live attenuated; Edmonsten Zagreb strain.

questions.text: A general mechanism of intracellular survival likely involves alteration of the microbial cell surface to avoid host killing factors. All of the following organisms are known to survive intracellularly except ?
questions.solution:
1. Streptococcus pyogenes grows extracellular and causes pyogenic infection.
  2. Intracellular bacteria are -
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Legionella
  • Yersinia
  • Salmonella typhi
  • Shigella
  • Neisseria
  • Mycobacterium
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Pneumococci

3. Obligate intracellular (Rickettsia, Chlamydia).

questions.text: A couple is using the calendar method for protection against unwanted pregnancies. The Standard Days Method (SDM) advises on avoiding unprotected sexual intercourse in which days of the menstrual cycle?

choices.text: From day 3 to 13 of menstrual cycle.
From day 8 to 28 of menstrual cycle
From day 8 to 21 of menstrual cycle
From day 3 to 19 of menstrual cycle

questions.solution:
Standard days method:

  • It is for the women having their cycle lengths between 26-31 days.
  • Have their fertile days between 8 to 19 days of the cycle.
  • Hence, SDM advises on avoiding unprotected sexual intercourse during these days [8 to 19 days] of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female visited the OPD with a concern about her increasing weight and difficulty in breathing while performing physical exercise. She informed the doctor that she has a family history of heart disease. What is the Goal of the Prudent diet for the prevention of Coronary heart disease?
questions.solution:
• The goal of WHO Prudent diet is to Reduce Cholesterol: HDL ratio <3.5
  • Prudent diet: Dietary modification is the principle preventive strategy in the prevention of CHD.

WHO recommended changes:

  • Reduction of fat intake to <20-30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats <7% of total energy intake
  • Reduction in cholesterol intake to <200 mg/day
  • Increase in complex carbohydrate consumption
  • Reduction of salt intake to < 5 gms per day
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption.

Extra edge:

Balanced diet contain: [carbohydrates> fats> proteins]

  • Proteins -10-15 % of daily energy intake [met first]
  • Fats - 15-30 %
  • Carbohydrates - constitute remaining energy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the hospital with a cough, runny nose, body pain, and fever for 5 days. Looking at the current scenario the physician gave him medications and asked him to stay under quarantine for 14 days. Quarantine was originally introduced as protection against?
questions.solution:
• In the 14th century, quarantine was introduced in Europe to protect against transmission of plague.
  • Ships, crews, travelers were detained for a 40 day period.

Also remember, the list of Quarantinable diseases:

  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious tuberculosis
  • Plague
  • Smallpox
  • Yellow fever
  • SARS
  • Viral hemorrhagic fever
  • Cholera
  • Flu

questions.text: In a study, it was found that eating vegetables rich in beta-carotene could reduce cancer. But there can be other factors like a high fiber diet, which could also be responsible for this. This is due to:
questions.solution:
• A high fiber diet is associated with vegetables rich in beta-carotene.
  • Also, a high fiber diet is associated with decreased incidences of certain cancers especially colonic cancers.
  • Now, since the high-fiber diet is present with both the cause and the effect independently and is distributed unevenly in the case and the control group, it can be called a confounding factor.
  • Also, it can be due to multifactorial causation, if both carotene and high fiber diet are associated with reduced cancer incidence.
  • Since we have to select only one option, and from other studies, we do know that vitamin doesn’t decrease the risk of cancer, the best option will be the confounding factor.

questions.text: The derivatives of the cannabis plant are known by many names – marijuana, weed, pot, ganja, charas, hashish, and more. They have a socio-religious association in India dating back hundreds of years, but never before have cannabis products been under so much scrutiny as they are now. The arrest of a Bollywood actress (now out on bail) by the NCB in the drug case related to another Actor's death has led to a larger debate. Which among the following is the active component of Ganja?
questions.solution:
Cannabis

  • Active Principle: Cannabidiol which is inert, is converted to active tetra-hydro cannabinol(THC) on exposure to heat
  • It does not produce physiological dependence or addiction, but psychological dependence and tolerance develop

questions.text: A 26-year-old female with h/o multiple sexual partners visited the gynecology OPD with odd smelling discharge from the vagina, pain during sex, and lower abdominal pain. Which of the following contraceptive is protective against the given condition?
questions.solution:
• Barrier methods especially male condoms and Female condoms give protection against STDs (including HIV), PID, and pregnancy.
  • IUDs increase the chances of PID.
  • Combined OCP decreases the chances of PID.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the OPD with maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, severe headache, and myalgia. On serological examination, Bartonella Quintana was found to be the causative organism. All of the following statements are true about the given condition except?
questions.solution:
Trench fever:

  • Aka 5 days fever, shin-bone fever, wolhynia fever, Quintana fever.
  • Caused by Bartonella quintana. ·Transmitted by pediculus corporis.
  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice.

Also, remember:

  • 3- day fever, sand-fly fever.
  • 7-day fever: leptospirosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant female visited the hospital for a routine check-up. The physician advised her to get her serological tests done for hepatitis infection. Which of the following hepatitis is associated with higher mortality in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
HEPATITIS-E:

  • ·Calcivirus
  • ·HEV in pregnancy: the fulminant form of hepatitis E infection is seen during pregnancy with high case fatality rate.
  • ·HEV is essentially a waterborne disease; Feco-oral route of transmission
  • ·Incubation period: 21-45 days

Also, Remember

Hepatitis type Type Incubation period Route of transmission
A Entero-virus 72 [Picorna virus] 15-45 Days Feco-oral route - MC in children in India
B HepaDNA virus 45-180 Days Blood, sexual, parenteral
C Hepaci virus 30-120 days Blood, sexual, parenteral
D Viroids like 30-90 days Blood, sexual, parenteral

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the hospital with abdominal pain, diarrheal episodes, weakness, cough, and anemia. On examination, he was found to be positive for Casoni's test. The clinical diagnosis of hydatid cyst was made by the physician. Which of the following is the most common site of hydatid cyst in the human body?
questions.solution:
Hydatid disease:

  • Caused by infection with a small tapeworm parasite called Echinococcus granulosus.
  • The most common site of hydatid cyst in the human body is Right posterosuperior lobe of the liver.
  • In hydatid disease, 70% of cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver.
  • Rest are located in the lungs, brain, peritoneum, long bones, and kidney.

questions.text: A microbiologist has received two culture plates of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and Corynebacterium pseudotuberculosis. He has to culture and differentiate among them. Which of the following test should be conducted in order to biochemically differentiate C. diphtheriae from C. pseudotuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Solutions: -

→ C. pseudotuberculosis is urease positive and is thus differentiated from C. diphtheriae.

→ C. pseudotuberculosis causes caseous lymphadenitis in sheep and goats.

NON CORYNEBACTERIUM DIPHTHERIAE:

  1. C. parvum → immuno modulator
  2. C. jeikum → MDR isolate
  3. C. minutissimum → causes Erythrasma, coral red fluorescence is seen.
  4. C. pseudotuberculosis → causes animal diseases, also known as PREISZ NOCARD BACILLI.

Option 1: Corynebacterium- catalase positive.

Option 3: Oxidase positive organisms are:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Burkholderia species
  • Vibrio ·Pasteurella multocida
  • Brucella
  • Neisseria
  • Haemophilus spp
  • Campylobacter

Option 4: Potassium tellurite agar (PTA) is the selective media used for C. diphtheriae.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented with a 4 weeks history of pain and swelling in her left arm associated with fatigability, weight loss, night fever, and sweating. Laboratory test reveals that the peripheral blood count was unremarkable (hemoglobin 136 g/l, red blood cell count 8.9x, white blood cell count 3.05x, and platelet count 230x). The peripheral blood smear revealed no immature cells (41% neutrophils, 46% lymphocytes). Mantoux test was reactive (10 mm). Which is the most common lymphoma in adults with the given features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma.

DIFFUSE LARGE B-CELL LYMPHOMA:

  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL, with 25,000 new cases annually in the United States.

Morphology :

  • Common features are a relatively large cell size (4 to 5 times the diameter of small lymphocytes) and a diffuse growth pattern obliterating the underlying architecture. The nuclear shape is variable and vesicular in appearance, with 2 to 3 nucleoli; the cytoplasm is moderately abundant and can be pale or basophilic.

Immunophenotype :

  • These mature B-cell tumors express pan-B cell markers CD19 and CD20, with variable expression of germinal center B-cell markers (e.g., CD10 and BCL6); most have surface Ig.

Molecular Pathogenesis:

  • DLBCL is a heterogeneous group of lymphomas. Nevertheless, two chromosomal rearrangements are relatively common:
  • Thirty percent have translocations involving the BCL6 locus. BLC6 encodes a zinc-finger transcription factor that regulates the development and growth of germinal center B cells; over-expression holds cells in a relatively undifferentiated and proliferative state.
  • BCL6 can also silence the expression of p53. Somatic mutations in the BCL6 promoter can also lead to aberrant BCL6 expression.
  • White Blood Cells, Lymph Nodes, Spleen, and Thymus.
  • Between 1% and 20% have t(14;18)leading to over-expression of the anti-apoptotic BCL2 gene and may arise from the transformation of previously unrecognized follicular lymphomas. Tumors with BCL2 rearrangements also typically lack BCL6 rearrangements, suggesting that these constitute distinct molecular classes of DLBCL.

Special Subtypes of DLBCL Associated with Oncogenic Herpesviruses:

  • Immunodeficiency-associated large B-cell lymphomas occur in the setting of severe T-cell immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV and bone marrow transplantation). The neoplastic cells are often latently infected with EBV, which plays a critical pathogenic role. Restoration of T-cell immunity can lead to regression of the proliferation.
  • Primary effusion lymphomas arise as malignant pleural or ascitic effusions, mostly in advanced HIV infection or the elderly.
  • Tumor cells are anaplastic and lack T- or B-cell markers but have clonal Ig heavy chain gene rearrangements. Tumor cells are infected with human Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV)/ HHV8, which plays a causal role.

Clinical Features:

  • DLBCL occurs most frequently in older adults (median age of 60 years) as a rapidly enlarging, symptomatic mass at a single nodal or extranodal site (e.g., gastrointestinal tract, skin, bone, or brain).
  • Involvement of liver, spleen, and marrow can occur but usually later in the course.
  • DLBCL are aggressive, rapidly fatal tumors if left untreated. With intensive chemotherapy, complete remission is achieved in 60% to 80%, and 40% to 50% are cured; anti-CD20 immunotherapy improves initial responses and overall outcomes.
  • Patients with limited disease fare better than patients with widespread disease or a large bulky tumor mass.
  • DLBCL - Most common lymphoma in adults

Follicular lymphoma- Most common indolent lymphoma in adults

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia- Most common leukemia in adults

questions.text: The forensic team has concluded the autopsy on the 35-year-old railway employee's body recovered from the railway track about 2 km from the nearest station. Among the findings, the doctor has documented the presence of ipsilateral dilatation of the pupil and partial opening of the eyelids. This is known in forensic language as 'Le facies sympathique' and is seen in case of death by?
questions.solution:
Le facie sympathique:

  • One of the surest signs of ante mortem hanging.
  • Compression of the sympathetic chain by the knot of rope.
  • Results in ipsilateral dilatation of the pupil and partial opening of the eyelids.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient who complains of frequency and urgency of urination, pus-like discharge from the tip of the penis, swelling, and pain in the testicles was admitted to the hospital. The doctor took a swab and sent it for culturing in the laboratory. Which of the following culture media is used for this condition?

choices.text: Modified New York city agar medium

questions.solution:
Modified New York city agar medium is the culture media for Neisseria gonorrheae.

Culture media for Neisseria gonorrheae -

  1. Chocolate agar
  2. Thayer Martin media
  3. Modified New York city medium
  4. Martin Lewis Media

Answer to other options:

Bile Esculin (agar) hydrolysis test -

  • Positive = Blackening of the medium
  • Enterococcus ·Group D Streptococci

Mannitol salt agar -

  • Selective media for Staphylococcus aureus
  • Yellow colonies due to mannitol fermentation.

Blood agar -

  • Prepared by adding 5–10% of sheep blood to the molten nutrient agar at 45°C.
  • Enriched media and support the growth of all types of non-fastidious bacteria.
  • Shows hemolytic property.

questions.text: A 3-Yr-old child with abdominal mass crossing midline encasing aorta and IVC showing fine calcifications and Lytic bone metastasis. Which of the following is not a poor prognostic factor of the most probable diagnosis described here?
questions.solution:
Unfavorable prognostic factors in neuroblastoma:

  • Stage 3, 4 ·Age >18 months
  • Absence of evidence of schwannian stroma and gangliocytic differentiation
  • High Mitosis-karyorrhexis index (>200/5000 cells)
  • Near-diploid (segmental chromosome losses; chromothripsis)
  • MYCNAmplified
  • Chromosome 1p loss
  • Chromosome 11q loss
  • Absent TRKA expression
  • Presence of TRKB expression
  • Mutations of neuritogenesis genes

questions.text: A 33-year-old male, came in with a complaint of constant right upper back pain. On examination, you find that the pain was 2/5 on the visual analogue scale for pain and decide to give medication for the same. If you prefer to give oral medication, which of the following drugs do you think has maximum chances of absorption from gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
• Diclofenac sodium is a weak acid and is non-ionized in the acidic medium of the stomach.
  • Drugs, when in a similar medium are non-ionized and lipid-soluble. Therefore, Diclofenac sodium has the maximum chances of absorption from the stomach.
  • Other drugs given in the options are weakly basic drugs that are ionized at gastric pH.

Note:

  • Most of the drugs ending with 'INE' are basic in nature like morphine, quinidine, hyoscine, atropine, tubocurarine, etc.
  • Drugs forming salts with cations like sodium or potassium are acidic like diclofenac sodium, thiopentone sodium, etc
  • Drugs forming salts with anions like sulphate, phosphate, etc. are basic like morphine sulfate, chloroquine phosphate, etc

questions.text: A 27 Yr old female, H/O RTA came with Multiple lacerations over both the extremities and an inability to move the left leg. On examination,Patient lethargic, GCS Poor, Tenderness (+), Crepitus (+), Bony deformity(+) of the left leg. Vitals: HR = 120/min, RR = 20/min, BP = 80/60 mmhg. Managed with aggressive Fluid resuscitation and IV Antibiotics and analgesics. The major hemoglobin present in an adult is:
questions.solution:
• Major Hb present in adults is HbA1 [96%] → contain 2α and 2β chains.
  • Other Hb present in normal adult →3% HbA2 [α2δ2];1% HbF [α2γ2]

questions.text: A 66-year-old female came in with complaints of difficulty of breathing, dyspnea at rest and on exertion, heaviness in the left chest region for the past few months. ECG and Echo were done, revealing significant LV dysfunction and an EF of 40% and you make a diagnosis of Chronic CHF. You feel that a diuretic is mandatory in the treatment of this case. Which diuretic would you prescribe with zero fear of excessive K+ excretion?
questions.solution:
P: Potassium-sparing diuretics

A: Amiloride

S: Spironolactone

T: Triamterene

E: Eplerenone

questions.text: Poisoning with one of the following by itself is unlikely. The term 'gateway drug' is often used because using it leaves people susceptible to unknowingly ingest other substances. Experts have long warned of the dangers of the substance being laced with harmful drugs such as PCP, crack, or cocaine. It is known for its typical "burnt rope" odor. Which one among the following is being described here?
questions.solution:
Smell about mouth & Nose-

  1. Garlic-like - Phosphorus, Arsenic, Organophosphates, Thallium, Selenium, Dimethylsulphoxide.
  2. Sweetish or fruity -Ethanol, Chloroform, Nitrites.
  3. Acrid (pear-like) - Paraldehyde, Chloral hydrate.
  4. Rotten eggs-Hydrogen Sulphide, Mercaptans, Disulfiram.
  5. Fishy or musty - Zn Phosphide, Aluminium phosphide
  6. Bitter almonds -Cyanides, HCN
  7. Shoe polish -Nitrobenzene
  8. Burnt rope -Marijuana (Cannabis)
  9. Vinegar -Acetic acid

questions.text: A 21-year-old white woman was referred to a hospital after exposure to CO from a faulty furnace. She developed acute weakness, dyspnea, nausea, and vomiting. An ECG revealed sinus tachycardia, non-specific ST-T wave abnormalities, and a prolonged QTc interval. The chest X-ray revealed pulmonary edema and the 2-D echo revealed decreased LV systolic function with an EF of 25%. The treatment for this woman, among the following, would be?
questions.solution:
Treatment of carbon monoxide

  • Remove the victim from the source of exposure.
  • Maintain patent airway, fresh air, and orthobaric oxygen (high-flow or 100% oxygen at atmospheric pressure) Oxygen therapy is started if COHb > 10% and should be given for 4–6 hours
  • Blood transfusion, if required.
  • Gastric lavage to prevent aspiration pneumonia.
  • Cerebral edema is treated by mannitol

Extra: Tests that may be used for the diagnosis of CO poisoning:

  • Spectroscopy
  • Hoppe-Seyler's test
  • Kunkel's test
  • Potassium ferricyanide test
  • Katayama's test

questions.text: A 56 yr old man, Surender with heart failure is to be treated with a diuretic drug. Drugs A and B have the same mechanism of action. Drug A in the dose of 50 mg produces the same magnitude of diuresis as 500 mg of drug B. This suggests that:

choices.text: Drug B is less efficacious than drug A
Drug A is more potent than drug B
Drug A is a safer drug than drug B
Drug A will have shorter duration of action than drug

questions.solution:
• The drug producing the same response at a lower dose is more potent.
  • In this question, drug A is 10 times more potent than drug B. This data does not indicate anything about efficacy, safety, or duration of action.

questions.text: A 35-year man working in a wheat grain godown presented with fever and had axillary lymphadenopathy. The sample was sent to the laboratory to perform Wayson staining for the suspected organism. Reports confirmed Plague as the final diagnosis. What is the most likely vector responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Xenopsylla cheopis is the most likely vector responsible for Plague.

Option 2

Xenopsylla cheopis

  • It is the agent of plague, a zoonosis, transmitted from rodents by rat flea.
  • The natural reservoir for plague is rodents.
Option 1

Vector- Louse (Pediculus humanus corporis)

cause:- Trench fever
Option 3

Ixodid daminii:

the causative agent of Lyme’s disease
Option 4

Haemaphysalis spinigera:

the causative agent of KFD

questions.text: Bio-transformation is a metabolic process, that primarily occurs in the liver. Pro drugs such as ACE inhibitors (enalapril) are converted into active drug molecules through the action of which of the following hepatic enzymes?
questions.solution:
• All ACE Inhibitors (ending with -pril) are prodrugs except captopril, lisinopril, and enalaprilat.
  • Eg: Benazepril, enalapril, fosinopril, moexipril, perindopril, quinapril, ramipril and trandolapril, are all prodrugs.
  • They need to be converted to active form by the enzyme hepatic Esterases.
  • Ester moiety is removed by esterases and replaced with a hydrogen atom to form the active molecule.

Clinical implications:

  • In hypertensive urgencies, → Enalapril can’t be given because it is a prodrug, but its active moiety enalaprilat is used.
  • Also caution while using in hepatic failure patients

questions.text: A 9 Yr old boy, while riding a bicycle was hit by a four-wheeler and suffered generalized abrasions over both lower limbs, rushed to a nearby hospital. Inj. Tetanus toxoid was administered and wound cleaning and dressing done. All of the following statements are false regarding the given Pathology, except:

choices.text: Chemical mediators such as histamine play a role in delayed vascular leakage.
Hallmark of the given pathology is increased permeability in the post-capillary venules.
Transcytosis is not a contributing factor to vascular leakage.
In most cases, vascular leakage starts several hours after injury.

questions.solution:
*Several mechanisms are responsible for the increased permeability of postcapillary venules, a hallmark of acute inflammation.

  • Chemical mediators such as histamine, bradykinin, leukotrienes, elicit endothelial cell contraction which is the immediate transient response. ·
  • This results in increased interendothelial spaces - the most common mechanism of vascular leakage.
  • In most instances, leakage starts immediately after injury and is sustained for several hours until the damaged vessels are thrombosed or repaired.
  • Increased transport of fluids and proteins through the endothelial cell, called transcytosis, also contributes to vascular leakage.

questions.text: G2P1 with Rh-negative pregnancy with previously healthy child delivered at home by dai; had ABO incompatibility in present pregnancy. The characteristic feature on the peripheral smear is the presence of:
questions.solution:
In ABO hemolyt­ic disease of the newborn

  • The peripheral blood smear shows numerous spherocytes (predominate), occasional nucleated red cells, anisocytosis, and polychromasia.
  • The blood film in ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn (ABO HDN) is marked by the presence of microspherocytes.
  • Spherocytosis is attributed to the loss of membrane surface area when the spleen removes antigen-antibody complexes from the affected cell.

questions.text: A 48-Yr-old Male, Chronic Alcoholic for almost 30 years, now developed Liver Cirrhosis and fulminant hepatic failure. Liver Transplantation done, the patient was doing fine until day 3 Postoperatively. On Day 4 patient developed sudden onset Fever, chills, and rigor. Vitals: SpO2= 88 %, HR = 110/min, RR = 24/min. All of the following regarding the condition described above are true, except:

choices.text: CD8+ T-cells directly destroy the graft
It is the principal cause of early graft failure
Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor
Cytokines secreted by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation which destroys the graft

questions.solution:
Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.

Acute graft rejection:

  • It occurs within days or weeks after transplantation and is the principal cause of early graft failure.
  • Divided into two types:
  • In acute cellular rejection, CD8+ CTLs may directly destroy graft cells, or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines and induce inflammation, which damages the graft.
  • In acute antibody-mediated (vascular, or humoral) rejection, antibodies bind to vascular endothelium and activate complement via the classical pathway.

questions.text: In a population of 1000, there are 200 eligible couples. 30 out of them use condoms, 20 use IUCD, 20 use OC pills while 70 have undergone female sterilization. The rest do not use any method. Calculate the Couple protection rate.
questions.solution:
• Given, total eligible couples = 200 ; eligible couples protected by any of approved methods = 30+20+20+70 =140
  • CPR = Total no. of eligible couples protected by any of approved methods÷Total no. of eligible couples in the community×100

=140/200 = 70%

Approved methods of Family planning

1.Sterlization

2.IUD

3.Condom

4.Oral pills

In India, to achieve NRR=1 which means a two-child norm in which one girl is born to a couple the couple protection rate(CPR) should be 60%.

questions.text: The extent to which a specific health care treatment, service, procedure, program, or other intervention does what it is intended to do when used in a community-dwelling population is termed its:-
questions.solution:
• Effectiveness looks at how the intervention works in real-life settings.
  • Efficacy tests the same [how the intervention works] in controlled or laboratory settings.
  • Effect modification is all about stratification & occurs when exposure has a different effect among different subgroups. Effect modifications associated with the outcome but not exposure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female recently delivered a healthy baby in your hospital. She wants to undergo a sterilization operation to prevent unwanted pregnancies in the future. Which of the following is the correct Ideal time to perform Post-partum sterilization as per government of India guidelines?

choices.text: From 12 hours to 7 days of delivery
From 24 hours to 7 days of delivery
From 48 hours to 7 days of delivery

questions.solution:
Surgical procedure timings for female sterilization

  • Post-partum sterilization can be done after 24 hours up to 7 days of delivery
  • Interval sterilization: Within 7 days of the menstrual period
  • Sterilization with medical termination of pregnancy: performed concurrently
  • Sterilization following spontaneous abortion: performed provided the client fulfills the medical eligibility criteria

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with discolored patches on the skin, blister formation, numbness and weakness in hands and feet, loss of eyebrows and eyelashes. The physician sent the sample to the microbiology laboratory to find the causative agent. Which of the following culture medium is used to culture the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Leprosy:

  • Oldest disease known.
  • Caused by Mycobacterium leprae.
  • Mode of transmission: Air droplets, skin contact, transplacental, breastfeeding, insect bite, tattoo, corneal/organ transplantation.
  • Mycobacterium leprae has no artificial culture media.
  • Leprae bacilli are cultured by:
  • Footpad of mice.
  • 9-banded armadillo.

Other options:

  • ·Bordet gengou medium: Bordetella Pertussis.
  • ·LJ medium: Mycobacterium Tuberculosis.
  • Loeffler’s serum slope: Corynebacterium Diphtheria.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female was brought to the emergency with complaints of fever, palpitations, abdominal pain, and diarrhea in the past few hours. Though you thought of an infectious cause, while reviewing systems, you notice that the patient had tremors and profuse sweating since the same time the loose bowel movement began. ECG revealed Atrial fibrillation and now you feel it could be a thyroid storm. Which of the following anti-thyroid medications would you give her?
questions.solution:
Thyroid storm is an extreme form of thyrotoxicosis. The drugs used in thyroid storm are:

  • Propanolol to control severe cardiovascular manifes­tations. It is a life-saving drug used for cases of thyroid storm.
  • CCBs like Diltiazem are used if beta-blockers are C/I (as in asthmatics).
  • Propylthiouracil is used to reduce the synthe­sis of thyroid hormones. It is the anti thyroid DOC for thyroid storm.
  • Hydrocortisone is used to protect the patient against shock.

questions.text: A 33 Yr old male complained of Itching and generalized redness who developed erythematous pruritic lesions all over the body after washing his clothes 2 days back. The patient then went to a General Physician who prescribed him Injection Chlorpheniramine and Tablet Cetrizine. All of the following statements are true related to histamine, except:

choices.text: Histamine is a principal mediator of immediate transient response during acute inflammation.
It increases the permeability of venules
Histamine receptor agonists are used to treat allergies.

questions.solution:
Option 4 is a false statement since H1 receptor antagonists are used in treating allergies.

Histamine

  • Stored as preformed molecules in mast cells and is therefore among the first mediators to be released during inflammation.
  • Causes dilation of arterioles and increases the permeability of venules.
  • Can cause contraction of some smooth muscles such as in the lungs.
  • H1 receptor antagonists that bind to and block the histamine receptors are used for inflammatory reactions (allergies).

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented to the hospital with abdominal pain, loose watery stools, nausea, bloating, and fever. Suspecting diarrhea the doctor started his treatment with ORS. Which of the following is incorrect about ‘ reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution?
questions.solution:
• WHO UNICEF recommended oral rehydration formulation: reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution.
  • WHO reduced osmolarity oral rehydration solution.
Composition Weight Osmolar concentration (mmol/litre)
Sodium chloride 2.6 gm Sodium 75
Potassium chloride 1.5 gm Potassium 20
Sodium citrate 2.9 gm Chloride 65
Glucose, anhydrous 13.5 gm Citrate 10
Glucose, anhydrous 75
Total 20.5 gms Total 245

questions.text: A 23-year-old male bitten by a tick presented to the hospital with headache, nausea, muscle aches, and blackened crusted rash on the site of the bite. The physician sent him for performing an indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) with the R.rickettsii antigen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vectors of rickettsia disease:-

Spotted fever GROUP

Tick

Nil

questions.text: A 30-year-old male bitten by a street dog presented to the OPD. On examination, multiple facial bites with continuous oozing of blood were seen. Which of the following is not a part of management in grade III dog bite infected with rabies?

choices.text: Stitch the wound with antibiotic coverage
Administration of anti-rabies serum and vaccination.

questions.solution:
*Stitching the wound with antibiotic coverage is not part of management in grade III dog bite infected with rabies.

TYPES OF BITES:

→ CLASS I BITES: No prophylaxis required.

  • Licks over intact skin

→ CLASS II BITES: Post-exposure prophylaxis required.

  • Licks over broken skin
  • No oozing of Blood

→ CLASS III BITES: Post-exposure prophylaxis+ Igs

  • Facial Bites
  • Constant oozing of blood
  • Untraceable animal after bite
  • Wild animals bites

Management:

  1. The wound should never be stitched immediately to prevent additional trauma that may help in the spread of the virus in the deeper tissue.
  2. “If suturing is necessary, then it has to be done after 24-48 hrs later, applying minimum stitches under the coverage of anti-rabies serum locally”- Park.
  3. Cleansing – wound should be scrubbed well immediately with soap & water – soap kills the virus effectively.
  4. Chemical treatment- the wound is treated with quaternary ammonium compounds (like cetavlon or tincture iodine).
  5. Category III (Major risk):

Recommended prophylaxis (WHO)- Wound management, Rabies immunoglobulin, Rabies vaccine, Observe the dog for 10 days.

questions.text: You join work in Australia as a full-time consultant in pediatrics. When you return home tired from your duty, you park the car in the garage hastily and hang the keys on the wall. Suddenly a spider jumps onto your hand and bites on the dorsal surface. You push it away, washed your hands immediately. After a few minutes, you develop redness, swelling, and pain at the bite site and feel a bit nauseous. You rush back to the garage to see what bit you and take the car to the hospital, but you notice you are having tremors. Hence you call for the ambulance and inform what to keep ready, since the spider that bit you (as shown in the image below), is known to produce a toxin that causes-

choices.text: Blocking Active transport of ACh into synaptic vesicle

questions.solution:
The spider shown in the image is a Black widow spider & is known to cause excessrelease of Acetylcholine

Black widow spider toxin

  • Induces massive release and depletion of acetylcholine
  • Decrease release of Acetylcholine
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Inhibits synthesis of Acetylcholine
  • Hemicholinium (HC3) blocks choline uptake (the rate-limiting step in Ach synthesis) and depletes Ach.
  • Active transport of ACh into the synaptic vesicle
  • Inhibited by Vesamicol.

questions.text:
