You are appointed as the lecturer in the newly opened government medical college of your village. The schedule insists that you complete the topic of medications acting on different parts of GIT by this week. During the lecture about treatment modalities for GERD, you question one of the students, ‘Ranitidine differs from cimetidine in the following ways except?’
What is the answer you expect from them?

choices.text: It does not have anti-androgenic action
It produces more CNS side effects

questions.solution:
Cimetidine is rarely used now because:

  • It is the least potentH2 blocker
  • It is a short-acting agent
  • It is a potent inhibitor of microsomal enzymes
  • It can cause gynecomastia
  • It produces more CNS adverse effects

questions.text: A 28-year-old male with a history of dog bite 10 days ago presented to the OPD with fever, agitation, confusion, headache, and excessive salivation. The clinical diagnosis of rabies was made. Which of the following route causes the spread of the rabies virus?
questions.solution:
Solutions:

- Rabies Virus spreads by neural route.

Option 1:Rabies: single-stranded RNA Virus.

The virus may enter the peripheral nervous system directly at the site of the bite. In some cases, however, it may replicate in muscle tissue after entering the host.

The virus infects the sensory neurons and moves rapidly by axonal transport centripetally to the central nervous system (CNS)for replication.

  • Mode of transmission – Bite (most common), lick on abrasion, corneal transplant, airborne.
  • Mode of spread – Neural
  • Speed of rabies progress in sensory nerve – 3mm/hr.

Option 2:Poliovirusspread by the hematogenous route.

The infection causes destruction of cells in the anterior horn of the spinal cord (LMN death).

Signs of LMN (Lower motor neuron) lesion: asymmetric weakness, hypotonia, flaccid paralysis, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, muscle atrophy.

Respiratory muscle involvement leads to respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 49-Yr-old male complaints of sudden onset of difficulty in breathing when he climbs up the stairs associated with diaphoresis and palpitations. Patient is a known case of Hypertension for 15 years & on irregular compliance to antihypertensive drugs. ECG taken which revealed LVH. ECHO was done which revealed Ejection fraction of 40%. All of the following are transcription factors activated by signal transduction pathways of the given pathology, except:
questions.solution:
→ In the given clinical scenario, Patient has Cardinal symptoms of Heart failure,

  • Palpitations
  • Diaphoresis
  • Dyspnea on exertion

→ Patient is a known case of Hypertension with poor compliance to Antihypertensive drugs which lead to Left Ventricular Hypertrophy which concomitantly explains Heart failure , Echocardiography revealed an ejection fraction of 40%, which is usually seen in chronic pressure and volume overload conditions.

→ Signaling pathways which trigger hypertrophy activate a set of transcription factors such as:-

  • GATA 4
  • Nuclear factor of activated T-cells (NFAT)
  • Myocyte enhancer factor-2 (MEF2).

These transcription factors work in coordination to increase the synthesis of muscle proteins that are responsible for hypertrophy.

CARD→MLL 1(Mixed lineage leukemia protein-1) is a gene involved in acute leukemia.

questions.text: The forensic doctor has completed the autopsy of the 30-year-old man who has succumbed to injuries sustained in a road traffic accident. During his initial observation, on noting a bruise over a particular region, he has mentioned the possibility of a fracture of the middle cranial fossa with underlying brain trauma. What location of the bruise would have helped the doctor arrive at that conclusion?
questions.solution:
Battle's sign:

  • Bruising/ecchymosis over the mastoid process in the line of the posterior auricular artery.
  • It is an indication of fracture of the middle cranial fossa of the skulland may suggest underlying brain trauma

questions.text: A 40-year-old male visited the hospital for a permanent sterilization operation. The physician explained to him about the vasectomy method. Which of the following is not true regarding ‘no scalpel’ vasectomy?

choices.text: Special instruments are used to deliver the vas instead of cutting the skin
Scrotal skin is cut with LASER to expose the vas
The failure rate is same as that of conventional vasectomy
It is a very popular method in China

questions.solution:
• No scalpel vasectomy (also called keyhole vasectomy or NSV) is a vasectomy procedure variant in which a sharp hemostat is used to puncture the scrotum to access the vas deferens instead of giving an incision as in conventional vasectomy.
  • No cuts are made in no-scalpel vasectomy, but the skin is punctured.
  • The failure rate is the same as that of conventional vasectomy.
  • It is a very popular method in China.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient was found unconscious under a tree and was brought to the emergency department where he regained consciousness. He said that he had taken shelter under a tree during a storm. He also said that he had remembered nothing after the sound of the lightning. His arterial BP was 130/75 mmHg, his pulse was 85 per minute, and his fingertip O2saturation was 98%. The results of a neurological examination were normal and his GCS score was 15. His hearing and the tympanic membrane were found to be normal. There were significant Lichtenberg figures on the patient's back, extending over the right scapula. These characteristic burns are also known as?
questions.solution:
Filigreeburns or Arborescent or fern-like injury or Lichtenberg figures

  • Pathognomonic for lightning injury
  • Superficial, irregular red marks, may follow skin creases, especially if damp from sweating. (fern-like pattern).
  • The erythematous marks are not burns.

Cause: Different authors have suggested different causes

  1. The lesion occurs when an individual struck by a negative lightning bolt is then hit by a secondary positive flashover from a nearby grounded object.
  2. It represents an entrance point in an individual struck by a positively charged lightning bolt.
  3. Slight staining of tissues by hemoglobin from lysed red blood cells along the path of electric current.

Option 1, Crocodile flash burns: Multiple burnt or punched-out lesions are produced due to the air dancing over the body surface over large areas.

Option 2, Adipocere: a variation of putrefaction. It is seen most commonly in bodies immersed in water or in damp, warm environments. In adipocere, fat undergoes hydrolysis to free fatty acids by virtue of endogenous lipases and bacterial enzymes.

Option 3, Mummification: Another modified form of putrefaction, where drying and desiccation of the tissues occur instead of liquefaction, depending upon the conditions prevalent at the terminal stages.

questions.text: A 62-year old male went to our emergency with complaints of frequent and painful headaches. The patient denied diabetes and hypertension. The patient was initially medicated with intravenous Metamizole and monitored. The pain did decrease, although it returned four hours later. The patient was submitted to magnetic resonance imaging of her head. Diagnosis of a large meningioma was promptly made. which of the following Radiological sign seen in meningioma?
questions.solution:
• Meningiomas show intense contrast enhancement with Early enhancement and Delayed Washout (Early to come and Late to Go) which has been referred to as Mother in Law Sign
  • Owls eye sign - spinal cord ischemia
  • Tiger Eye Sign - Halloverden Spatz Disease
  • Inverted Napolean Hat Sign - b/l Spondylolisthesisof L5 over S1 in the frontal pelvic radiograph

questions.text: A person with aortic stenosis could perform exercise for 11 minutes in Bruce protocol. Exercise had to be stopped due to fatigue. He had a peak systolic gradient of 60 mm Hg across the aortic valve at rest. The best management for him would be?

choices.text: Aortic valve balloon dilation to prevent worsening

questions.solution:
• Diagnosis: Severe AS as trans-valvular peak gradient of 60 mmHg.
  • Since patient managed to perform on the Treadmill for up to stage 3 (beyond 9 minutes) of Bruce protocol without any ECG changes - ASYMPTOMATIC SEVERE AORTIC STENOSIS.
  • In Modified Bruce protocol, there are 7 stages of 3 minutes each on a treadmill, for which the patient walks on the treadmill at a gradually increasing speed..
  • There is a change in guidelines with surgery being indicated for asymptomatic severe AS due to progressive nature of disease.

Indications for Aortic valve replacement:

    • An abnormal response to treadmill exercise.
    • Rapid progression of AS, especially when urgent access to medical care might be compromised
    • Very severe AS defined by a valve area <0.6 cm2.
    • Severe LVH suggested by a wall thickness of >15 mm.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of sudden onset palpitations and dizziness. He is a k/c/o COPD and developed a viral upper respiratory infection for which he was taking an over-the-counter decongestant. Shortly thereafter he started experiencing palpitations. O/E - Pulse = 150/ min. , Rhythm = regular, BP = 80/60 mm Hg. ECG was done which shows the following findings. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• ECG reveals saw tooth waves ofatrial flutter with variable AV block.
  • Atrial flutter results from an abnormal circuit inside the right atrium, or upper chamber of your heart. It beats extra fast, about 250-400 beats per minute. A normal heartbeat is 60-100 beats per minute.

questions.text: A 29 y.o female came to the casualty with c/o bloody nipple discharge and a palpable mass in her left breast. On physical examination, a palpable mass of 1cm noted in her left breast along with nipple retraction. Various investigations were done which revealed stage-ll invasive breast cancer. The patient was advised for Breast conservative surgery. All are contraindications for breast conservation surgery in patients with newly diagnosed primary breast cancer except:

choices.text: Two distinct tumors in two different quadrants
Grade 3 poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma

questions.solution:
*Option 3 is not a contra-indication of Breast Conservation Surgery.

Breast conservation surgery(BCS) involves resection of the primary breast cancer with a margin of normal-appearing breast tissue, adjuvant radiation therapy, and assessment of regional lymph node status.

Resection of primary breast cancer otherwise called lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, segmental mastectomy, segmentectomy, tylectomy, and wide local excision.

The breast specimen that is removed is oriented and its edges are inked. Specimen radiography should be done for non-palpable lesions. The surgical defect is closed in a cosmetic fashion. Surgical staging of axilla performed through separate incision. Sentinel lymph node biopsy has replaced axillary lymph node dissection in clinically node negative patients. Clinical trials comparing mastectomy and breast conservation demonstrated equivalent survival

*Breast conservation surgery is currently the standard of treatment for women with stage 0, I, II invasive breast cancer.

Prerequisites for BCS include adequate tumor to breast ratio(small tumor large breast), patient willing to attend postoperative radiation therapy, and postoperative surveillance. The adequate margin for BCS according to NSABP B-06 trials is “no ink on tumor” Recurrence rate after BCS depends on several factors -Young age, high-grade tumors, involved resection margin are associated with increased risk of local recurrence. Patients with positive margins should have a further local excision

Contraindications to BCS

Absolute Relative

Diffuse suspicious or malignant appearing microcalcification throughout the breast

Multicentric tumors

Diffusely positive pathologic margins

RT during pregnancy

Homozygous for ATM mutation

Multifocal disease requiring two or more surgical incisions

Active connective tissue disease involving skin(scleroderma and lupus)

Women with a known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer

Prior RT to chest wall or breast

Other contraindications include inflammatory breast cancer, inadequate tumor to breast size ratio. Although high nuclear grade, presence of lymphovascular invasion, and negative steroid hormone receptor status have all been linked to higher local recurrence rates, none of these factors are considered contraindications to breast conservation

Multicentric- more than one distinct tumor in more than one quadrant

Multifocal- more than one distinct tumor within the same quadrant

questions.text: A preterm neonate was delivered by a primigravida with a birth weight of 1600 grams and. 3 weeks Prior to delivery, amniocentesis was done in order to know the status of lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. What does the L/S ratio determine?
questions.solution:
The Lecithin-Sphingomyelin (L/S) Ratio:

  • Used for assessment of fetal lung maturity prenatally by testing amniotic fluid obtained by amniocentesis.
  • Lecithin is produced in the lungs by type II alveolar cells and eventually reaches the amniotic fluid via the effluent from the trachea.
  • It is performed by thin-layer chromatography.
  • By 35 wk, the lecithin: sphingomyelin (L:S) ratio averages about 2:1, indicative of lung maturity.
  • Hence the risk of RDS is very low if the L/S ratio is >2.

questions.text: A woman presents 2 weeks after the intake of medical abortion pills with a history of minimal bleeding after intake of pills. She did not pass any clots or fleshy mass. On ultrasound, there is a single live intrauterine pregnancy. The doctor suggests that she may continue the pregnancy if she wishes, however, there is a small risk of fetal malformation. Which of the following syndromes, the baby may be born with?
questions.solution:
• Moebius syndrome results from the underdevelopment of the VI and VII cranial nerves.
  • It is characterized by facial paralysis and the inability to move the eyes from side to side.
  • Most people with this syndrome are born with complete facial paralysis and cannot close their eyes or form facial expressions.
  • There is a strong association between Moebius syndrome and antenatal use of Misoprostol.

questions.text: The Fontan procedure refers to any operation that results in the flow of systemic venous blood to the lungs without passing through a ventricle. It is performed to treat several complex congenital heart abnormalities including tricuspid atresia, pulmonary atresia with an intact ventricular septum, hypoplastic left heart syndrome, and double-inlet ventricle. Which among the following is a contraindication to this procedure?

choices.text: Left ventricular diastolic pressure of 12 mmHg
Pulmonary vascular resistance in excess of 4 Woods

questions.solution:
Fontan operation

The long term goal of single ventricle palliative is to optimize ventricular function and promote systemic oxygen delivery

A direct connection between the branch pulmonary arteries and systemic venous return without an intervening power source was initially proposed by Fontan. It is now the treatment of choice for children born with all varieties of single ventricle

Thus blood flow in the Fontan circuit is passive, being promoted only by the pressure differential between the systemic venous system and pulmonary venous atrium

The Fontan is usually performed when the child is between 2 and 4 years of age. Pulmonary vascular resistance should be below4 Woods units and the ejection fraction should be more than 45% to ensure success. There should be normal left ventricular diastolic pressure (between 5 and 12 mm Hg)

Established criteria for creating an effective Fontan circulation include

  • The ability to connect the systemic venous return surgically to the pulmonary arteries in an unobstructed manner
  • Normal pulmonary artery architecture and resistance
  • Normal pulmonary venous drainage and low left atrial pressure
  • Absence of significant A-V valve regurgitation
  • Good ventricular function
  • Unobstructed systemic arterial outlet
  • Good aortic valve function

Today, the most widely practiced modification of the Fontan operation is the total cavopulmonary connection i.e. connection of the divided superior vena cava to the superior and inferior aspects of the right pulmonary artery along with the creation of a channel to direct the IVC flow into the pulmonary arteries

questions.text: A 60-year-old male who was a known case of systemic hypertension admitted with the history of unconsciousness since 2 hours.The patient was intubated and connected to mechanical ventilator in view of poor GCS(3/15). On examination, blood pressure-130/70 mmHg; pulse rate-120/minute; SpO2-98%. CT brain showed massive intracranial hemorrhage due to hypertensive bleed. After clinical examination, the neurosurgeon declared that the patient was brain dead. The clinical criteria which do not include to declare brain death in this patient would be-
questions.solution:
Brain Death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain functions and the criteria will be applicable only in the absence of hypothermia,hypotension,metabolic or endocrine abnormalities,neuromuscular blockers and drugs known to depress the brain function.

Clinical Criteria

  • ·Coma
  • ·Absent motor activity including no decorticate or decerebrate posturing,respiratory effort (apnea)

*Spinal reflexes may be preserved in some patients

  • Absent brainstem reflexes
  • Fixed, mid - dilated pupil
  • Absent corneal reflex
  • Absent oculovestibular reflex (Cold caloric)
  • Absent oculocephalic reflex (Doll's eye movement)
  • Absent gag and cough reflex

Apnea testing (positive)- no respiratory effort (apnea) with the arterial CO2tension atleast 60 mmHg or 20 mmHg above the pretest level.

questions.text: A 21-year-old girl started on antipsychotic by a primary care physician, due to a psychotic breakdown. It is noticed that she has developed amenorrhoea, decreased sexual desire and galactorrhoea as an adverse event to the drug. Which of the following dopamine pathway is involved in this adverse event to the drug?
questions.solution:
4 important pathways of Dopamine and their importance
Mesocortical pathway Negative symptoms of Schizophrenia
Mesolimbic pathway Positive symptoms of Schizophrenia
Nigrostriatal pathway Extrapyramidal symptoms
Tuberoinfundibular pathway Hyperprolactinemia

Prolactin:

  • Anterior pituitary hormone
  • Dopamine inhibits secretion of prolactin through the tuberoinfundibular pathway
  • Antipsychotics block the dopamine D2 receptors in this pathway to increase prolactin levels.
  • Hyperprolactinemia secondary to antipsychotic use can explain the amenorrhoea, decreased libido and galactorrhoea
  • Prolactin levels are positively associated with severity of tardive dyskinesia and negative symptoms of schizophrenia

HOW TO REMEMBER -

TIP= Tubero-infundibular pathway is responsible for milk from breast tip ( prolactin increase )

questions.text: Chanda rani, a 60-years-old female presented to OPD with complaints of breathlessness. She explained that she feels comfortable while sitting or lying down but feels breathlessness in upright position. Examination revealed Tachycardia, Tachypnea and decrease in systolic blood pressure in the upright position. The likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Platypnea - Orthodeoxia syndrome

  • Characterized by dyspnea and deoxygenation accompanying a change to a sitting or standing position from a recumbent position.

Causes of Platypnea

  • ASD or PFO with position-dependent shunting
  • Other Cardiac conditions:
  • Pericardial effusion
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Pulmonary
  • Multiple pulmonary emboli
  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Radiation-induced bronchial stenosis
  • Hepatopulmonary syndrome
  • Pulmonary A-V communications
  • PCP pneumonia
  • Hepatic cirrhosis

Orthopnea

  • Dyspnea is seen in supine position and reduces in sitting position.
  • Due to acute CHF and bilateral diaphragmatic hernia.

questions.text: A 56yrs old, female patient presented with complaints of gradually increasing dyspnea on exertion over the past 2yrs. On examination, she has an apical diastolic murmur. On further work up with echocardiography, Hockey-stick appearance is seen. Which of the following is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
HOCKEY STICK SIGNS
ECG

Digoxin effect
Echocardiography

Mitral stenosis.

  • Normal, biphasic, and rapid motion of the mitral valve is altered because it opens only partly and as a single unit.
  • The posterior leaflet becomes immobile and the anterior mitral leaflet tethering results in a "hockey stick" appearance.
  • These changes obstructs the blood flow from the atrium to the ventricle
MRI Brain
  • Hockey-stick sign of v CJD
  • FLAIR image shows symmetrical pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclear hyperintensity.
  • This combination gives a characteristic "hockey-stick" appearance.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer 2 years back, presents to the emergency department with headache, backache, and frequent vomiting. She is extremely thirsty and confused. Which test is most likely to identify the cause?
questions.solution:
Here, the patient, a known case of breast cancer operated 2 years back, now presents with symptoms of bone metastasis such as backache, headache, and frequent vomiting. The metastasis to the bone causes increased osteoclastic activity in bone leading to hypercalcemia. Increased thirst sensation and confusion are symptoms of hypercalcemia. Hence the investigation needed to be done now is serum calcium concentration

Hypercalcemia is defined as a serum calcium level above the normal range of 8.5 to 10.5 mEq/L or an increase in the ionized calcium level above 4.2 to 4.8 mg/dL. Primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy from either bony metastasis or secretion of the parathyroid hormone-related protein, account for most cases of symptomatic hypercalcemia

Multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and solid tumors metastatic to bone ( particularly breast, lung, and prostate cancer) cause hypercalcemia by excessive osteoclastic activity

Symptoms of hypercalcemia

Gastrointestinal -Anorexia, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain

Neuromuscular - weakness, confusion, coma, bone pain

Cardiovascular - Hypertension, arrhythmia, polyuria, worsening of digitalis toxicity. ECG changes include shortened QT interval, prolonged PR and QRS intervals, increased QRS voltage, T wave flattening and widening, and atrioventricular block

Renal - polydipsia

Definitive management of hypercalcemia depends on the correction of the primary problem. Patients with a malignant neoplasm and hypercalcemia may respond to surgical excision, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy. Symptomatic patient with severe hypercalcemia related to the malignant disease can be quickly and effectively treated by saline infusion followed by the administration of a loop diuretic to induce saline diuresis with associated urinary calcium clearance

Severe hypercalcemia referred to as hypercalcemic crisis occurs with serum calcium concentration above 14mg/dL and is related to the release of calcium from bone by tumor; it can be managed by administration of bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate disodium, and etidronate disodium. They have a potent capacity to reduce the osteoclast-mediated release of calcium from bone

questions.text: A woman presents for the first time at 26 weeks gestation. An ultrasound done reveals anencephaly. AFI is 26cm. All of the following are possible mechanisms for increased liquor in this patient, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Anencephaly isa lethal NTD characterized by the absence of the brain and cranium above the base of the skull and orbits.

It can be diagnosed as early as the first trimester on USG.

Polyhydramnios is commonly seen due to the following reasons:

  1. Transudation of fluid across the membranes
  2. The absence of swallowing
  3. Absent fetal pituitary (absence of ADH hormone implies that the baby passes more urine).

questions.text: A gynecological surgeon is performing a hysterectomy for a case of endometriosis with pelvic adhesions. On opening the abdomen, there are multiple adhesions obscuring pelvic anatomy. Which of the following is an INCORRECT statement regarding normal pelvic anatomy?

choices.text: The ureter lies beneath the uterine artery
The mucosa of the fallopian tube is lined by ciliated cells
The pouch of Douglas lies between the bladder and the uterus
External iliac artery lies superior to ovarian fossa

questions.solution:
• The ureter lies beneath the uterine artery (Water under the bridge)
  • The mucosa of the fallopian tube is lined by ciliated cells
  • The pouch of Douglas is posterior to the uterus lying between the rectum and the uterus.
  • The ovarian fossa is bound superiorly by external iliac artery and vein, anteriorly by broad ligament, posteriorly by ureter, internal iliac artery and vein, inferiorly by obturator nerve and vessels

questions.text: A fire broke out in a slum after the cylinder burst and it was fire all over. The fire brigade, NDRF personnel's and ambulance arrived area of causality and recovered as many people as they could. The district hospital was informed and they prepared themselves for the same. How will you as an intern present in the emergency calculate the amount of fluid to be given in the case of children based on Parkland formula?
questions.solution:
• In children with burns, Parkland formula is an appropriate starting guideline for fluid resuscitation (4 mL lactated Ringer solution/kg/% TBSA burned)

(TBSA – Total body surface area)

  • Half of the fluid is given over the 1st 8 hr; the remaining half is given in the next 16 hours

questions.text: A man is found to be always punctual and frugal. He is quite distressed about small deviations and mistakes from others. He is noticed to keep things clean and organized manner. His relatives inform that he always has been like this and sometimes causing significant distress to people around him. This could be the presentation in which of the following clinical scenarios?
questions.solution:
Obsessive compulsive personality disorder (OCPD) is not OCD.

OCPD is also called as Anankastic personality disorder. It comes under cluster C of the DSM 5 criteria.

Important features seen in OCPD:

  • Stickler to rules and regulations
  • Specific about minor details
  • Preoccupied to cleanliness
  • Prefer organized and planned schedule – uncomfortable with sudden changes
  • Frugality Lack of flexibility

questions.text: The neural crest is a highly migratory multipotent cell population that forms at the interface between the neuroepithelium and the prospective epidermis of a developing embryo. Following extensive migration throughout the embryo, NC cells eventually settle to differentiate into multiple cell types. Which of the following is not a neural crest derivative?
questions.solution:
Sphincter pupillae is derived from neurectoderm not mesenchyme or neural crest cell


Neural Crest Derivatives:

  • Corneal Keratocytes
  • Ciliary muscles
  • Corneal stroma and endothelium (endothelial cells and keratocytes)
  • Pericytes of choroidal membranes
  • Melanocytes
  • Ciliary ganglion
  • Stroma of Iris and choroid Trabecular meshwork

Extraocular muscles are mesodermal in origin

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with features of poor perfusion following MI. On examination, heart rate is 40/min with BP of 60 mmHg systolic. Atropine was given twice over 5 minutes, but the condition of the patient is not improving. What is the next best step?
questions.solution: ACLS 2015 guidelines: Case of symptomatic bradycardia with signs of poor perfusion-->Transcutaneous pacing is recommended.

questions.text: A woman presents for contraceptive counselling. She is 32 years old and has no contraindications for use of Oral contraceptive pills. The doctor tells her that the failure rate of these pills is less than 1 per HWY (Hundred Woman Years). This failure rate is calculated as?

choices.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies
Total accidental pregnancies × 100 / Number of women Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy
Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy

questions.solution:
The use-effectiveness of contraceptive method is expressed as Pearl rate & life table technique.

  • Pearl rate or pearl index was introduced by Raymond Pearl in 1932. The rate is expressed as pregnancy rate per 100 women years (HWY) & calculated as

Pregnancy rate per HWY = Total accidental pregnancies × 1200/ Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive

*1200 is the number of months in 100 years

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has recurrent episodes of vaginal discharge and pain abdomen that subside with antibiotics. All of the following may be possible mechanisms of infertility in this patient, EXCEPT?

choices.text: Loss of cilia of the fallopian tubes
Loss of Peristalsis of the fallopian tubes

questions.solution:
This appears to be a case of infertility secondary to recurrent PID (vaginal discharge and pain abdomen)

Important factors for Infertility in a case of PID are—

  • Cornual block,
  • Loss of cilia,
  • Loss of peristalsis due to thickening of the tubal wall,
  • Closure of the Abdominal ostium and distortion of the tube due to Peritubal adhesions.

questions.text: A 35-years-old chronic smoker came with a history of hoarseness, foreign body sensation for the last 6 months. 2 weeks back, the patient developed pain during swallowing. your ENT professor diagnosed it as laryngeal carcinoma and asked for Supravital staining. What is the stain used in this method?
questions.solution:
SUPRAVITAL STAINING AND BIOPSY:

  • Supravital staining with 1% toluidine blue is useful in the early detection of malignancies. TB stain is of value due to its high sensitivity.
  • It is useful in high-risk populations to enable earlier detection. It assists in selecting the best site for biopsy. It is very useful in developing countries like India because of the cost-effectiveness and easy technique. The test is a sensitive, simple, non-invasive, and highly cost-effective procedure
  • Toluidine blue is an acidophilic dye of the thiazine group that selectively stains acidic tissue components (carboxylates, sulfates, and phosphate radicals) such as DNA and RNA. Its use in vivo is based on the fact that dysplastic and anaplastic cells contain quantitatively more nucleic acids than normal tissues. In addition, malignant epithelium may contain intracellular canals that are wider than normal epithelium; this is a factor that would enhance penetration of the dye.
  • Toluidine blue is applied to the laryngeal lesion and then washed with saline.
  • Carcinoma in situ and superficial carcinoma takedye while leukoplakia does not.
  • SUDAN BLACK STAIN: Used for staining of fats and fat droplets.
  • METHYLENE BLUE -Used to stain certain body fluids and tissues easier to view during surgery
  • METHYLENE GREEN -Used for staining DNA

questions.text: An obstetrician is assessing the pelvis of a primigravida to rule out cephalopelvic disproportion. She tries to reach the sacral promontory with her index and middle fingers with the base of the index finger at the lower end of the pubic symphysis estimates this diameter to be around 12 cm. Which of the following is the correct interpretation?

choices.text: The diameter measured 12 cms indicates adequate inlet
This diameter indicates status of mid pelvis

questions.solution:
DIAMETER OF INLET vs CONTRACTED INLET

True conjugate (AP diameter): 11 cm

Obstetric Conjugate (AP diameter, 1.5-2cm less than diagonal conjugate) : 10 cm

< 10 cm

Diagonal Conjugate (AP diameter) : 12 cm

< 11.5 cm

Transverse diameter : 13 cm

< 12 cm

Oblique diameters : 12 cm

*The largest diameter of the inlet is transverse diameter 13 cm

AP diameter is least at the pelvic brim

The obstetric conjugate is the diameter of the pelvic inlet and is obtained by subtracting 1.5-2cm from diagonal conjugate, which can be measured clinically by trying to reach the sacral promontory with the index and middle fingers with the base of the index finger at the lower end of the pubic symphysis

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient clutches his chest and falls down. A physician arrives on the scene and finds the patient unresponsive with no breathing efforts. What is the first thing to be done by the physician?
questions.solution: In such a case, the physician should first 'Call for help'

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as her menses last for 6 to 7 days each month. Her cycles are regular but the mother is worried since she and her older daughter have menses lasting only 3 to 4 days. The physician clarifies that the normal duration of menstrual flow would last between:
questions.solution:
Duration of menstruation → 2-7 days

Amount of blood loss → 20 to 50 mL with an average of 35 mL.

Nearly 70 percent of total menstrual blood loss occurs in the first 2 days.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is involved in an automobile accident with resultant injuries including bilateral closed femur fractures, left pulmonary contusion, and closed head injury. On post-injury day 4, significant upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage begins. Endoscopic examination reveals an area of confluent ulceration with bleeding in the gastric fundus. Endoscopic hemostasis fails. Appropriate immediate management includes:

choices.text: Lavage of gastric contents with iced saline
Visceral angiography and embolisation of bleeding vessel

questions.solution:
Stress-related gastritis is characterized by the appearance of multiple superficial erosions of the entire stomach, most commonly in the body. It is due to acid and pepsin injury in the context of ischemia from hypoperfusion states. These lesions are different from the solitary ulcerations, relating to acid hypersecretion that can occur in patients with severe head injury ( Cushing ulcers). Cushing described the appearance of acute peptic ulceration in patients with head trauma

Risk factors for the development of stress erosions

  • Multiple trauma
  • Head trauma
  • Major burns
  • Clotting abnormalities
  • Severe sepsis
  • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome
  • Cardiac bypass
  • Intracranial operations

Patient with clinical evidence of a GI bleed should receive endoscopy within 24 hours and while awaiting for it , they should be treated with a proton pump inhibitor

Endoscopic therapy is instituted if bleeding is active or when bleeding is stopped if there is a significant risk of rebleeding. Forrest classification to assess rebleed. Grade IA, Ib, IIa have a high risk of rebleed

Forrest class Endoscopic appearance
High risk
1a Active spurting bleeding
1b Active oozing bleeding
2a Non-Bleeding visible vessel
2b Adherent clot
Low risk
2c Pigmented clot
3 Clean base ulcer

In those who develop significant bleeding,acid-suppressive therapy is often successful in controlling haemorrhage. In rare cases when this fails, consideration should be given to the administration of vasopressin or octreotide, endoscopic therapy, or even angiographic embolization.

Identification and treatment of the source of bleeding is essential which can be achieved with endoscopy, angiography, or occasional laparotomy.

Endoscopic control of bleeding can be achieved with epinephrine, electrocoagulation, laser coagulation, heater probe, argon plasma coagulation, clip application, banding, etc.

Visceral angiography is indicated for patients who are actively bleeding or when endoscopy fails to control the bleeding. When an actively bleeding vessel is identified, embolization with gelatin sponge, autologous blood clot, coils often controls the bleeding.

Infusion of vasopressin may be used in patients with severe stress ulceration and ongoing bleed

The surgical choices included vagotomy and pyloroplasty with oversewing of the hemorrhage or near-total gastrectomy

questions.text: Parents bring their 8-year-old child to the dentist after he had a blow on the face by the football while playing with his friends. one incisor from the right upper quadrant & one from the right lower quadrant were broken and had to be taken out. How many permanent teeth will the child have at that time?
questions.solution:
Permanent teeth erupt in the following order:

  • First molar

6-7 years

  • Central and lateral incisors
    6-8 years
  • Canine and premolars
    9-12 years
  • Second molar
    12-13 years
  • Third molar
    18 years or later
  • So at the age of 8 years, first molar, central and lateral incisors would have erupted in each quadrant
  • Hence, a total of 12 permanent teeth will be present at the age of 8 years

questions.text: Dharamveer, a 55 years old retired navy personnel presented to the emergency 5 days back with complaints of chest pain, sweating and breathlessness for 1 hr. ECG showed Anterior wall MI. Angiography showed double vessel disease and Angioplasty was done. He is getting discharged today. All of the following drugs will be mentioned in the discharge card for secondary prevention of MI except?
questions.solution:
SECONDARY PREVENTION OF MI

Responsible for the improvement in the long-term mortality and morbidity rates after STEMI.

  1. Long-term treatment with an antiplatelet agent (usually aspirin) after STEMI is associated with a 25% reduction in the risk of recurrent infarction, stroke, or cardiovascular mortality. An alternative antiplatelet agent that may be used for secondary prevention in patients intolerant of aspirin is clopidogrel (75 mg orally daily).
  2. ACE inhibitors or ARBs and, in appropriate patients, aldosterone antagonists should be used indefinitely by patients with clinically evident heart failure, a moderate decrease in global ejection fraction, or a large regional wall motion abnormality to prevent late ventricular remodeling and recurrent ischemic events.
  3. The chronic routine use of oral beta-adrenoceptor blockers for at least 2 years after STEMI is supported by well-conducted, placebo controlled trials.
  4. Warfarin : not used routinely. Most physicians prescribe aspirin routinely for all patients without contraindications and add warfarin for patients at increased risk of embolism .
  5. Side effect: There is an increased risk of bleeding when warfarin is added to dual antiplatelet therapy. However, patients who have had a stent implanted and have an indication for anticoagulation should receive dual antiplatelet therapies in combination with warfarin

PRECAUTIONS

  1. Such patients should also receive a proton pump inhibitor to minimize the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
  2. Should have regular monitoring.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a unilateral erythematous ulcerative lesion in the nipple. Histopathology of the lesion showed large cells with clear cytoplasm and atypical nucleoli located between normal keratinocytes of the nipple epidermis. Which of the following statement is false regarding her diagnosis and management?

choices.text: Treatment is with warm compresses and antibiotics
Biopsy of the skin of nipple
Usually associated with an underlying breast carcinoma

questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Paget's disease. Warm compress with antibiotics (option A) is not an appropriate treatment option for her.

  • Treatment involves mastectomy with axillary staging or wide local excision of nipple and areola(BCT) to achieve clear margins, axillary staging, and radiation therapy. For patients with BCT, surgery should include excision of the full nipple-areola complex with a cone of underlying retro areolar tissue and complete excision of any tissue with abnormal radiologic findings

Paget's disease accounts for 1% or less of breast malignancies. It is characterized by nipple erythema and irritation and may progress to crusting and ulceration. The condition may also spread outward from the nipple and onto the areola and surrounding skin of the breast.

  • The differential diagnosis includes eczema, contact dermatitis, and post-radiation dermatitis
  • A biopsy should be performed and a specimen containing Paget cells (large cells with clear cytoplasm and atypical nucleoli) located between normal keratinocytes of nipple epidermis) confirms diagnosis. Paget cells spread into the lactiferous sinuses under the nipple and upward to invade the overlying epidermis of the nipple.
  • Paget cells do not invade the dermal basement membrane and are categorized as carcinoma in situ
  • More than 95% of patients have an underlying breast carcinoma
  • Paget's disease may be accompanied by a palpable mass in slightly more than 50% of patients

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presented to the emergency department with a four-hour history of the right lower quadrant (RLQ) abdominal pain. The pain originated in the umbilical region, radiating diffusely across the lower abdomen and subsequently localized to the RLQ. Over the counter, oral co-codamol 500mg (a combination analgesic of codeine phosphate and acetaminophen) was taken before presenting to the emergency department, which did not alleviate the pain. The pain was exacerbated by lifting the right leg and relieved by leaning forwards. The abdominal examination revealed a soft abdomen, tenderness on percussion, rebound tenderness in the RIF, and a positive psoas sign. The diagnosis of Appendicitis was made. Which of the following is the Most sensitive Investigation for this Condition?
questions.solution:
• CT is the more sensitive investigation to detect Acute Appendicitis than USG
  • USG is the preferred investigation for acute appendicitis in children and CT scan in Adults

questions.text: Mother was concerned for her 13 months old child whose teeth were not yet erupted as she remembers her first child had teeth by this time who is now 2 yrs old and upon bringing her child to the OPD, the doctor noticed bowed legs. Few tests were asked to be done in order to rule out which out of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Delayed dentition:-When no tooth has erupted by the age of 13 months.

Causes of delayed dentition:(Mnemonic - FRIIED ChoP)

  • Familial
  • Rickets
  • Idiopathic (Most common)
  • Incontinentia pigmenti
  • Endocrine causes: Hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism, hypopituitarism
  • Down syndrome
  • Cleidocranial dysplasia
  • Progeria

questions.text: Organ preservation is the supply line for organ transplantation. Currently, the liver, pancreas, and kidney can be successfully preserved for up to two days by flushing the organs with the University of Wisconsin (UW) organ preservation solution and storing them at hypothermia (0-5 degree C). The UW solution is effective because it uses a number of cell impermeant agents (lactobionic acid, raffinose, hydroxyethyl starch) that prevent the cells from swelling during cold ischemic storage. In this, hypothermia is a critical component for successful organ storage because:

choices.text: Oxygen is more soluble in cold solutions and provides a continual supply for energy metabolism
There is no way to suppress microbial growth except by cooling and slowing the growth rate
Hypothermia diminishes energy requirements and allows the limited energy reserve to keep the organ alive
It slows metabolism and the enzymic processes that would destroy the cell

questions.solution:
Organ preservation

This helps in extending the time that organs can be safely stored. The goal of preservation is to extend the period of organ viability

Hypothermia and pharmacological inhibition are the two most frequent methods. Both slow, yet cannot completely shut down the removed organ’s metabolic activity, so both have adverse effects such as cellular swelling and degradation

Cold storage solutions mitigate the adverse effects of hypothermia or pharmacologic inhibition alone. Such solutions help prevent cellular swelling, act as buffers to counter acidosis and electrolytes, the composition of which reflects that of intracellular rather than extracellular fluid

The most effective preservative solution is university of Wisconsin. Other solutions include histidine - tryptophan - ketoglutarate solution

Most organs are stored by static cold storage in an icebox at 4 degrees Celsius. Recent advances include storage by pulsation machine perfusion

Maximum and optimal cold storage times

Organ Optimum(hours) Safe maximum (hours)
Kidney <18 36
Liver <12 18
Pancreas <10 18
Small intestine <4 6
Heart <3 6
Lung <3 6

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presented to Pediatric OPD with a bump on her eyelid. Her mother reported that it started as a small lesion that has been progressively increasing in size over several weeks. On examination, a lipogranulomatous inflammation was noted. Your probable diagnosis would be
questions.solution:
Chalazion

  • Lipogranulomatous inflammation.
  • In case of recurrent chalazion or seborrheic blepharoconjunctivitis, rule out any sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • Incision and curettage is done from conjunctival side.
  • Horizontal incisions are avoided to minimize damage to meibomian ducts.

Tuberculosis, Fungal and viral agents cause infection and associated inflammation but not lipogranulomatous inflammation

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is on aspirin, ACE inhibitor, nitrates, and beta-blocker for chronic stable angina. Since the new year party, he is having long-lasting angina pain every day for the past 3 days. ECG was normal and Troponin I levels are normal. Which is the best management of this patient?

choices.text: Admit and observe for rising of cardiac biomarkers
Increase dose of long-acting nitrates and manage as outpatient

questions.solution:
• The patient is a known case of chronic stable angina and has presented with the development of unstable angina since angina episodes have become more pronounced and more frequent.
  • Antithrombotic therapy with heparin, abciximab, and intravenous beta blocker is recommended.
  • TIMI score is calculated subsequently to decide the need for a revascularization procedure.
  • Thrombolysis is contraindicated in unstable angina.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presented with a history of dyspnoea and recurrent bronchitis. On auscultation, a loud systolic murmur was detected. Her clinical examination was otherwise normal. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was done in the patient which showed an incomplete bundle branch block in the precordial lead. This is most consistent with which of the following?

choices.text: A sinus venosus Atrial septal defect with partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
An ostium primum Atrial septal defect

questions.solution:
Many patients with secundum ASDs have an incomplete bundle branch block on their ECG. This is in contradiction to patients with ostium primum defects, who often have a left axis deviation

An atrial septal defect (ASD) is defined as discontinuity of the interatrial septum that permits direct mixing of the systemic venous and pulmonary venous circulation

ASDs can be classified into three different types

  • Ostium Secundum type defect(deficiency of septum primum) - most prevalent (80%)
  • Ostium primum defects also described as partial or transitional AV canal defect
  • Sinus venosus type defects occurs as the result of embryologic malalignment between the superior vena cava or inferior vena cava. These defects are not associated with the ovale fossa and are frequently associated with partial anomalous pulmonary venous return(PAPVR)

ASDs result in an increased pulmonary blood flow secondary to the left to right shunting through the defect which in turn causes right ventricular volume overload which leads to right ventricular hypertrophy with elevated right ventricular end-diastolic pressure and relative pulmonary stenosis across the pulmonary valve because it cannot accommodate the increased right ventricular flow

On auscultation, they reveal the prominence of the first heart sound with the fixed splitting of the second heart sound. A diastolic flow murmur across the tricuspid valve and ejection flow murmur across the pulmonary valve may be heard

The electrocardiogram shows right axis deviation with an incomplete bundle branch block. When the right bundle branch block is associated with a leftward or superior axis, an AV canal defect should be strongly suspected

Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD) are a complex constellation of cardiac lesions involving the deficiency of the atrial septum, ventricular septum, and A-V valves

questions.text: An elderly male came to your clinic with a complaint of otalgia. On examination, you found that there is no clear ear pathology for the pain. So, you are thinking about referred otalgia. Which of the following will be the differential diagnosis of this scenario?
questions.solution:
• Referred otalgia is pain felt in the ear, although the source of pain is somewhere else. This happens when that organ shares the same nerve supply as the ear.
  • The larynx is supplied by the vagus which also supplies the ear.
  • The tongue and oral cavity are supplied by the lingual branch of the mandibular, Glossopharyngeal, and vagus, all of which also supply the ear.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is passing near to the styloid process. In a case of stylagia, it is the cause of referred otalgia

questions.text: A 64-year-old assistant hair stylist undergoes a vaginal hysterectomy under spinal anesthesia. Bleeding occurs when an attempt is made to separate and exclude the right ureter from the operating field. After a short interval, a respiratory arrest occurs and intubation was instituted. What is the most likely cause of respiratory arrest during this procedure under spinal anesthesia?

choices.text: Centrally induced mechanism secondary to decreased cardiac output
Diffusion of anesthetic to the level of the pons

questions.solution:
• Spinal anesthesia induces venous vasodilation because of sympathetic blockade.
  • Venous pooling can seriously impair venous return.
  • It is the sympathetic blockade and not somatic nerve blockade that is responsible for the vasomotor and respiratory changes.
  • It is important to ensure that volume depletion is corrected before spinal anesthesia because venous return and hence cardiac output are diminished.
  • These changes are aggravated by keeping the head up

questions.text: A mother brings her 5-year-old boy to medicine OPD with a complaint of fever for 5 days. O/E - the child has red eyes, dry, cracked lips and a rash on his hands and feet, and unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. He also had a red tongue as shown in the image below. Radiological imaging was done which showed the following findings. Choose the CORRECT statement regarding the disease depicted in the given images:

choices.text: IV immunoglobulin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
• The image shows a child with erythema over cheeks with evidence of stomatitis.
  • The angiography reports show multiple aneurysms in course of the left main coronary artery
  • Hence the diagnosis is Kawasaki disease.
  • Choice A is wrong as aspirin prevents the development of Myocardial infarction in a patient with Kawasaki disease.
  • Choice B is wrong as patients have bulbar congestion but an absence of any discharge.
  • Choice D is wrong as patients develop unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with fever in the initial part of the illness.

Diagnostic Criteria for Kawasaki Disease

Fever persisting at least 5 days with the presence of at least 4 features out of 5:

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Rash
  • Edema & erythema of palms & soles
  • Adenopathy
  • Mucosal involvement: Strawberry tongue

questions.text: A 38-year-old Lorry driver was driving for a long distance decided to take a nap, parked his vehicle on the side of the road and was sleeping under the lorry. Unfortunately another lorry driver who was driving under the influence of alcohol lost control and hit this lorry on the backside. The patient was brought to the ER after 2 hours of the incident. Proximal limb amputation is planned for this patient. What is the permissible ischemia time for this patient ?
questions.solution:
• Irreversible necrotic changes begins in muscles after 6 hours of ischemia(warm ischemia time), it is preferable to begin the replantation of parts with good muscular bulk (viz. parts proximal to palms and foot) within this time.
  • With cooling (to 4°C), this time may be extended to 12 hours (cold ischemia time).
Sequence of reimplantation(Mnemonic:BE FAN VS)
  • B- Bone (first to be implanted)
  • E- Extensor tendon
  • F- Flexor tendon
  • A- Arteries
  • N- Nerves
  • V- Veins
  • S- Skin (preserved first implanted last)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents at 32 weeks of pregnancy with complaints of urinary frequency, urgency, and lower abdominal pain. Urine culture shows E.coli. The patient states that she has had such symptoms a few times prior to this episode. All of the following conditions should be looked for in this patient, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
The patient has presented with a history of recurrent UTI.

Risk factors for UTI include a

  • Previous history
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Pregnancy
  • An underlying anomaly of the genitourinary tract such as tumors, calculi, strictures, VUR
  • Incomplete bladder emptying
  • Sickle cell disease

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman presents to the dermatologic clinic to evaluate her skin lesions. She states that it has been present for several years and is not associated with other symptoms. On examination following lesion is noted as shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fibroepithelial polyp

  • This is a case of fibroepithelial polyp in which the patient presents with complaints of skin lesion for several year and is asymptomatic.
  • Fibroepithelial polyp (Skin tag; Papilloma; Acrochordon)
  • Seen at sites of chafing such as the groin, axilla, or neck.
  • Benign and typically have a narrow stalk
  • Most cases are idiopathic but occasionally associated with insulin resistance.
  • Hanging or protruding polyps
  • Made of loosely arranged collagen fibers and blood vessels surrounded by the thick epidermis
  • Multiple causes include insulin resistance, human papillomavirus, acromegaly, and HIV.
  • Cryotherapy, surgical excision, and electrosurgery are the treatment options

Option A: Dermatofibromas

  • They are seen on legs or arms and are within the skin.
  • Painful nodule
  • The dimple sign is positive

Option C: Keratoacanthomas

  • They are benign tumors of the skin.
  • It contains a central plug of keratin.

Option D: Nodular BCC

  • Presents with nodule.
  • With or without central cystic change and telangiectasias.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of melena and significant loss of weight. On endoscopic evaluation, the patient was found to have a gastric ulcer in the lesser curvature. Multiple biopsies were taken and the histopathology report came out to be gastric adenocarcinoma. All of the following conditions are associated with increased risk of gastric cancer except:
questions.solution:
*Multiple endocrine neoplasia type I (MEN 1) is not associated with an increased risk of gastric cancer.

Factors increasing or decreasing the risk of gastric cancer

Increase risk

  • Family history
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Blood group A
  • Diet(high in nitrates, salt, and fat, smoked/cured foods, low vitamin A and C, well water)
    Gastric bacteria convert nitrate to nitrite, a known carcinogen
  • Familial polyposis
  • Gastric adenomas
  • Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer
  • Helicobacter pylori infection
    Atrophic gastritis, intestinal metaplasia, dysplasia
  • Previous gastrectomy or gastrojejunostomy (>10 years ago)
  • Radiation exposure
  • Coal workers, rubber workers
  • Tobacco use
    Tobacco use probably increases the risk of stomach cancer and alcohol use probably has no effect
  • Epstein Barr virus
    About 10% of gastric adenocarcinoma carry the EBV virus
  • Genetic factors
    The most common genetic abnormalities in sporadic gastric cancer affect the p53 and COX 2 gene. A germline mutation in the CDH1 gene encoding E-cadherin was shown to be associated with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer. Prophylactic total gastrectomy should be considered in patients with these mutations
  • Menetrier’s disease

Decrease risk

  • Aspirin
  • Diet(high fresh fruit and vegetable intake)
  • Vitamin C

Premalignant conditions of the stomach

  • Atrophic gastritis
    By far, the most common precancerous lesion. Helicobacter pylori is critical in the pathogenesis. Correa described three distinct patterns of chronic atrophic gastritis - autoimmune, hypersecretory, and environmental
  • Hyperplastic polyp (>2cm)
  • Intestinal metaplasia
  • Adenoma
    Patients with familial adenomatous polyp have a high prevalence of gastric adenomatous polyps
  • Benign gastric ulcer
    All gastric ulcer should be viewed as malignant until proven otherwise with adequate biopsy and follow up
  • Stomach remnant
    Gastric cancer can develop in the gastric remnant following subtotal gastrectomy. They most commonly develop near the site of anastomoses. Bile or alkali reflux gastritis following Billroth II gastroenterostomy has been implicated as a precursor

Neither MEN 1 nor MEN 2 is associated with gastric cancer

MEN 1- Multiglandular parathyroid disease, Neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, Adenomas of the anterior pituitary

MEN 2A- Medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, parathyroid adenoma

MEN 2B- Medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in early pregnancy presents with pain abdomen. Ultrasound reveals a clear endometrial stripe of 14 mm and a gestational sac-like structure with some hemorrhage, surrounded by ovarian follicles. A provisional diagnosis of ovarian ectopic is made. Which of the following is the other most important differential diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
• Findings of ectopic pregnancy in the ovary are likely to mimic those of tubal pregnancy or a bleeding corpus luteum.
  • At surgery, early ovarian pregnancies are likely to be considered corpus luteum cysts or a bleeding corpus luteum.

Here, since there is a lesion in the ovary, it could also be a corpus luteum cyst with hemorrhage and a very early intrauterine pregnancy as suggested by increased endometrial thickness ( first sign of pregnancy)

questions.text: A couple married for 8 years, having 2 children uses condoms along with spermicidal jellies for contraception. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding spermicides found in vaginal foams, creams, and suppositories?

choices.text: Contain Non-ionic surfactants causing osmotic changes resulting in the killing of sperms.
They act as a physical barrier to the transport of the sperm
'Immediate douching' is a must after intercourse to avoid Irritant action
Do Not have STD/HIV protection action

questions.solution:
Spermicides function by :

  • Providing a physical barrier to sperm penetration
  • These have chemical spermicidal action i.e. nonionic surfactants that alter sperm surface membrane permeability, causing osmotic changes resulting in the killing of sperms
  • The active ingredient is nonoxynol-9 or octoxynol-9.
  • Improve the contraceptive effect of barrier methods like diaphragms, cervical caps, and condoms.
  • No STD protection provided by these
  • Spermicides must be deposited high in the vagina in contact with the cervix shortly before intercourse.
  • Their duration of maximal effectiveness is usually no more than 1 hour, and thereafter, they must be reinserted before repeat intercourse.

Douching is avoided for at least 6 hours after coitus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient develops sudden left lower chest pain and epigastric pain after vomiting. The patient shows diaphoresis, breath sounds are decreased on the left, and there is abdominal guarding. How will you confirm your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pain is a striking and consistent symptom and strongly suggests that an esophageal rupture has occurred, particularly in the cervical area following instrumentation of the esophagus or substernal in a patient with vomiting.

  • Pain is often described as excruciating and frequently masquerades as a dissecting aneurysm, perforated ulcer, or myocardial infarction. If subcutaneous emphysema is present, the diagnosis is almost certain.
  • Suspicion of esophageal perforation begins with symptoms of epigastric or chest pain, neck or throat pain, and dysphagia. Physical examination findings might include crepitus on the neck, chest, or face; neck swelling; epigastric tenderness; nasal voice, or sometimes normal examination findings. Within the first 8 to 24 hours following injury, frank sepsis may develop if the contamination is extensive Mediastinal emphysema, a strong indication of perforation takes at least 1 hour to be demonstrated and is present only in 40% of patients.
  • Mediastinal widening secondary to edema may not occur for several hours In cervical perforation, cervical emphysema is common and mediastinal emphysema is rare, the converse is true for thoracic perforation
  • If mediastinal pleura ruptures, pneumothorax appears rapidly

Etiology

  • Barotrauma (spontaneous perforation, Boerhaave’s syndrome) is a serious type of perforation which occurs due to an abrupt increase in intraluminal pressure of the esophagus during forceful emesis leading to full-thickness rupture of the esophageal wall. The condition was first identified by Boerhaave
  • Spontaneous rupture of the esophagus is associated with a high mortality rate because of the delay in recognition and treatment. Spontaneous rupture usually occurs into the left pleural cavity or just above the GEJ
  • The most common cause of esophageal perforation currently is iatrogenic injury following esophageal instrumentation, accounting for nearly 60% of all cases

Investigations

Initial screening evaluation is with a plain upright chest radiograph which may reveal a pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, subcutaneous or mediastinal emphysema or mediastinal widening suggestive of perforation. But a normal X-ray does not rule out the possibility of a leak

Abnormalities of chest radiogram are dependent on three factors :

  • The time interval between perforation and radiographic examination
  • Site of perforation
  • The integrity of the mediastinal pleura

The diagnosis is confirmed with a contrast esophagogram which will demonstrate extravasation in 90% of patients. The use of water-soluble medium such as Gastrografin is preferred due to concern of exacerbating contamination if barium were used and leaked. 10% false-negative rate is noted. CT is another diagnostic modality that can be used

Management:

The principles of management after diagnosis include:

  • Treatment of contamination
  • Wide local drainage
  • Source control
  • Enteral feeding access

The most favorable outcome is obtained following the primary closure of the perforation within 24 hours, resulting in 80% to 90% survival. If the time delay before closing a perforation approaches 24 hours and the tissues are inflamed, division of the cardia and resection of the diseased portion of the esophagus is recommended.

Cameron proposed three criteria for non-operative management of oesophageal perforation:

  • Perforation well contained in the esophagus
  • Symptoms should be mild
  • Minimal evidence of clinical sepsis

questions.text: A 56-year-old man attends having knocked his finger while working in the garage. He reports having had a small lump on his finger for some months and, since knocking his finger, this has been leaking, as shown below. What is the single most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Myxoid cysts

  • Ganglions of the distal interphalangeal joint.
  • They grow slowly and often cause grooving of the nail as they grow.
  • They are benign but can become painful.
  • Treatment is by aspiration of the thick jelly inside or injection with steroid, or surgical excision if they recur.

- A keratoacanthoma has a plug of keratin in the center.

- Pyogenic granuloma usually grows rapidly at the site of trauma.

- Sebaceous cysts are not typically seen on digits.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with primary infertility and dysmenorrhea. An ultrasound done suggests an endometriotic cyst of 8 cms in the right ovary. Which of the following is the appropriate management?

choices.text: IUI as early as possible, to utilize the remaining fertility potential
Ovulation induction and follow a fertile period

questions.solution:
An infertile patient with an endometriotic cyst is best treated by excision of the cyst followed by medical treatment of infertility including ovulation induction, IUI, or assisted reproduction.

Surgical management of endometriosis broadly includes:

  1. Patients with infertility: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy, adhesiolysis, and electrocoagulation of endometriotic implants
  2. If the Family is complete and the patient has severe pain or menstrual complaints: Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustained an injury to the spleen in a road traffic accident. A primary and secondary survey of the patient found the patient to be hemodynamically stable without associated injuries clinically. Which among the following is the diagnostic modality of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a hemodynamically stable patient with splenic trauma, the diagnostic modality of choice is CT scan to grade the severity of splenic injury

Splenic trauma

  • Spleen is the most commonly injured organ in abdominal trauma
  • Splenic trauma include left upper quadrant or flank ecchymosis and abrasions as well as left shoulder pain caused by irritation of the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic blood (Kehr’s sign)
  • Regardless of the mechanism, all trauma patients should receive the primary survey followed by secondary evaluation
  • Currently, the accepted standard of care for most splenic trauma is expectant management with close observation
  • Operative intervention is reserved for the hemodynamically labile patient who shows active signs of haemorrhage and who doesn’t respond appropriately to fluid resuscitation
  • For those with normal hemodynamics, a primary survey followed by focused abdominal examination (ecchymosis, abrasions, flank pain, and distension) is done
  • Evaluation of hematocrit, hemoglobin, platelet, and coagulation profile should be done followed by focused abdominal sonography for trauma(FAST)
  • FAST offers a rapid and noninvasive approach for detecting intraperitoneal bleed
  • In stable patients, an abdominal CT scan with an injection of an iv contrast agent is the diagnostic modality of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries
Grade Injury description
I Hematoma Subcapsular, < 10% surface area
Laceration Capsular tear, < 1 cm parenchymal depth
II Hematoma Subcapsular, 10-50% surface area
Intraparenchymal, < 5 cm diameter
Laceration 1-3 cm parenchymal depth not involving a parenchymal vessel
III Hematoma Subcapsular, > 50% surface area or expanding
Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma
Intraparenchymal hematoma > 5 cm
Laceration > 3 cm parenchymal dept or involving trabecular vessels
IV Laceration Laceration of segmental or hilar vessels producing major devascularization (> 25% of the spleen)
V Laceration Completely shatters spleen
Vascular Hilar vascular injury which devascularized spleen
  • Nonoperative management includes bed rest, serial abdominal examination, and hemoglobin and hematocrit monitoring. This with angiography especially for grade III and IV injuries offers a splenic salvage of up to 95%
  • Indications for angiography and embolization - contrast extravasation, pseudoaneurysm, significant hemoperitoneum, high-grade injury, and evidence of a vascular injury
  • After initial resuscitation, splenic injuries are managed operatively by splenectomy, partial splenectomy, or splenic repair (splenorrhaphy) based on the extent of the injury and the physiological condition of the patient

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the office for routine follow-up. She has occasional numbness in her feet. The patient takes ibuprofen for chronic back pain along with hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. Urinalysis shows albuminuria. Lisinopril therapy is initiated . The next day, the patient returns due to lightheadedness and near-syncope. Her blood pressure is 80/45 mm Hg . Which of the following is most likely the major factor contributing to this patient's current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with albuminuria was started on an ACE inhibitor for treatment of early diabetic nephropathy.

Although most patients remain asymptomatic with only a mild reduction in blood pressure, first-dose hypotension can be a potential limiting factor when initiating ACE inhibitors.

*Significant hypotension is most likely to occur in patients with high plasma renin activity, such as those with volume depletion (eg, from diuretic use [hydrochlorothiazide in this patient]) or heart failure.

Initiation of ACE inhibitor therapy causes abrupt removal of the vasoconstrictive effects of angiotensin II, resulting in decreased peripheral vascular tone and a precipitous drop in blood pressure in susceptible patients.

To prevent the development of first-dose hypotension, therapy should be started at low doses and slowly titrated upward as needed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old women recently underwent glaucoma filtering surgery presented to the eye clinic with complaints of loss of central vision and distortions .On clinical examination, her IOP is 7mm Hg and there is optic nerve swelling associated with folding of the retina and choroid in the posterior is noted. The ophthalmologist diagnosed this as a case of Hypotonous maculopathy. Which of the following is not a cause for this condition ?
questions.solution:
Suprachoroidal Hemorrhage is not a cause of hypotony maculopathy.

Hypotony maculopathy is low IOP associated with chorioretinal folds near macula, optic nerve head edema and vessel tortuosity.

Causes

  • Postoperative Hypotony
  • Mitomycin C (MMC) toxicity of the ciliary body
  • Overfiltering Bleb
  • Wound Leak
  • Traumatic Hypotony
  • Scleral perforation
  • Retinal Detachment
  • Cyclodialysis
  • Bilateral Hypotony
  • Osmotic Dehydration
  • Diabetic coma
  • Uremia

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the casualty with sudden syncopal episode while playing with his grandchildren. He is currently alert and describes occasional substernal heaviness and shortness of breath. His lungs have bibasilar rales and BP is 120/80mmHg. Which is the classical finding expected in this patient?

choices.text: Ejection systolic murmur with Soft S2
Ejection systolic murmur with wide split S2
Harsh pan-systolic murmur with loud S2

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of exertional syncope, angina equivalent and dyspnea in geriatric age group points to diagnosis of valvular Aortic stenosis.

In aortic stenosis

  • Soft S2( due to poor mobility of a stenosed valve)
  • REVERSE S2 SPLIT
  • S3, S4 in advanced cases
  • Ejection Click
  • Ejection systolic murmur
  • Pulsus et tardus

So, option A is correct

  • Choice B is wrong because in aortic stenosis, narrow split S2 or paradoxical split S2 is heard.
  • Choice C and D are wrong due to presence of Ejection systolic murmur in aortic stenosis.

Points to remember

  • Ejection systolic murmur = aortic stenosis / pulmonary stenosis
  • Pan systolic murmur = VSD, chronic MR, Chronic TR
  • Wide split S2 = VSD, MR, Pulmonary stenosis, RVF
  • Loud S2 = Pulmonary hypertension, systemic hypertension

questions.text: A 21-yr-old lady had undergone Septal surgery. She was discharged after surgery & informed to meet a consultant after 2 days for pack removal. She did not attend her appointment. After 15 days, she came back to the ENT clinic with nausea, Vomiting, hypotension & rash along with purulent secretions from the nose. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME:

  • Rare after septal surgery.
  • Can follow staphylococcal (sometimes streptococcal) infection
  • Characterized by nausea, vomiting, purulent secretions, hypotension and rash.
  • Should be diagnosed early.
  • Treated by removal of packing, hydration, maintaining BP and administering proper antibiotics.

questions.text: A 30-year old male brought by relatives with a history of abdominal gunshot injury. On examination patient’s general condition was poor - restless and disoriented. His pulse was -130/min. & Blood Pressure-90/60 mm of Hg. and Breathing rate was 35/min. On Per abdomen examination, the bullet entry wound was on the Left side of the abdomen, left upper lumbar region. Abdominal distention was present. The peritoneal breach was present on palpation (finger exploration of the wound). Generalized abdominal tenderness with guarding was present. All the following compensatory mechanism occurs in this patient except:

choices.text: The juxtaglomerular apparatus in the kidney produces renin
There is afferent arteriolar constriction and efferent arteriolar dilatation
GFR starts declining, when the mean arterial pressure falls below 80 mmHg

questions.solution:
Patient with pulse rate 130/min and blood pressure of 90 mm Hg following a gunshot wound indicate that the patient is in a state of class III hemorrhagic shock

Table 1 Stage classification of hemorrhagic shock committee on trauma advanced trauma life support (ATLS) (2004). American College of Surgeons, Chicago, 7th edition (12)

Symptoms Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV
Blood loss (% blood volume) 15 15-30 30-40 >40
Blood loss (mL) 750 50–1,500 1,500-2,000 >2,000
Heart rate (1/min) <100 >100 >120 >140
Blood pressure (mmHg) Normal Normal Reduced Reduced
Breathing rate (1/min) 14-20 20-30 30-40 >35
Consciousness Low restlessness Moderate restlessness High-grade restlessness, Disorientation, Disorientation lethargy

A decrease in systolic blood pressure is not a reliable early sign of hypovolemia because blood loss must exceed 30% before hypotension is evident

The following are the compensatory mechanisms in response to hypovolemic shock. The earliest compensatory mechanism in response to a decrease in intravascular volume is an increase in sympathetic activity which is mediated by pressure receptors or baroreceptors in the aortic arch, atria, and carotid bodies. Heart rate and contractility are increased, peripheral vascular resistance is also increased resulting in increased BP. Blood is shunted from less critical organs (skin, skeletal muscle, splanchnic circulation) to more critical organs (brain, liver, and kidneys)

The juxtaglomerular apparatus in the kidney- in response to vasoconstriction and decrease in blood flow -produces the enzyme renin which generates angiotensin I

In the lungs, the angiotensin-converting enzyme converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II which stimulates an increased sympathetic drive and causes the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines. The catecholamines are thought to be responsible for the elevated glucose levels seen in hemorrhagic shock

In the adrenal cortex, the zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone in response to angiotensin II which causes increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion. Angiotensin II also has a direct effect on renal tubules reabsorbing sodium

Antidiuretic hormone is released from the pituitary causing retention of free water at the level of kidney

GFR is maintained by prostaglandin-mediated dilatation of afferent arterioles and angiotensin II-mediated constriction of efferent arterioles. Once the mean arterial pressure falls below 80mmHg, renal autoregulation fails and GFR declines steeply

The neurohumoral mechanism to hypovolemia stimulates an increase in renal tubular sodium and water reabsorption. Therefore the urine sodium concentration is typically <20mM in nonrenal causes of hypovolemia, with a urine osmolality of >450m Osm/kg. The reduction in Gfr and distal tubular sodium delivery may cause a defect in renal potassium excretion with an increase in plasma potassium concentration

PrerenalFailures Intrinsic RenalFailure Postrenal
Urine osmolality (mOsm/L) >500 <350 variable
Urine sodium (mOsm/L) <20 >50 >50
Fractional excretion of sodium <1% >3% variable
Urine,plasma creatinine level >40 <20 <20
Urine, plasma urea level >8 <3 variable
Urine,plasma osmolality <1.5 >1.5 variable
Blood urea nitrogen/serum creatinine level >20 <10 variable

Patients with hypovolemic shock present with an increase in BUN and creatinine, reflective of a decrease in GFR

Prolonged renal hypoperfusion may lead to acute tubular necrosis, an intrinsic renal disease

Acute kidney injury can be detected by the following criteria

  • Rise in serum creatinine of 26 μmol/L or greater within 48 hours
  • More than or equal to 50% rise in serum creatinine known or presumed to have occurred within the past 7 days
  • Fall in urine output to less than 0.5ml/kg/hr for more than 6 hours in adults and more than 8 hours in children
  • More than 25% fall in estimated glomerular filtration rate in children and young people within the past 7 days

questions.text: A 48-year-old chronic smoker who underwent foot amputation for peripheral vascular disease has come for follow up. You're the Orthopaedic intern in the OPD. He is asking about prothesis and his lifestyle after rehab. The following movements are true about SACH foot prosthesis except

choices.text: Does not look like a normal foot

questions.solution:
In SACH foot there are no ankle movements. Hence squatting is not possible.

Prosthesis SACH foot(Western) (Solid ankle cushion heel) Jaipur foot By Dr. P k Sethi
Appearance Does not look normal. Requires shoe Looks normal. Can walk barefoot
Keel Long Keel restricting movements Small keel allowing all movements
Ankle movements Not present. Squatting not possible Present. Squatting possible(sit on ground)
Inversion / Eversion (subtalar joint movements) Not present. Hence difficult to walk on uneven grounds Present.so can walk on uneven grounds
Cost High Low

questions.text: Neurocristopathy is a diverse class of pathologies that may arise from defects in the development of tissues containing cells commonly derived from the embryonic neural crest cell lineage. Which of the following below is a type of neurocristopathy ?
questions.solution:
ICE syndrome is a type of neurocristopathy which is because of disorder of migration of neural crest cells

ICE Syndrome

  • The most important feature of this group of diseases is the movement of endothelial cells off the cornea onto the iris.
  • ICE Syndrome is seen characteristically in middle aged women with unilateral involvement with variable corneal, iris involvement leading to pupillary abnormalities.
