  • Secondary Glaucoma occurs due to proliferation of the iris tissue leading to block of the trabecular meshwork.

ICE Syndrome consists of 3 disorders with overlapping clinical features

  • Progressive (Essential) Iris atrophy - Characterized by severe iris involvement with iris atrophy, correctopia, polycoria. Secondary glaucoma is common
  • Chandler syndrome - Corneal endothelium involvement leading to a hammered silver appearance which is characterized by corneal edema leading to visual blurring and coloured haloes
  • Cogan Reese (Iris Naevus) Syndrome - characterized by diffuse naevus on the anterior iris, mild to moderate iris atrophy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with sudden onset visual loss affecting the right temporal region. Ultrasound of the globe demonstrated right-sided retinal detachment with an associated well-defined flat echogenic mass, refer to the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and accounts for 80% of all uveal melanomas.

The incidence of these tumors increases with age.

Clinical presentation may range from no symptoms over various types of visual disturbances to visual loss.

Ultrasound is an excellent modality for examining the globe and can visualize small plaque-like or discoid uveal melanoma, with a thickness of less than 3 mm, which are usually difficult to assess on CT or MRI.

Typical USG Features include: hypo-to-isoechoic "collar button" or "mushroom" shaped lobulated mass with internal vascularity

questions.text: A 28-week newborn, birth weight 1000 grams delivered by a 28 yr old multigravida, h/o pre-eclampsia. After the baby is delivered, swelling over the fontanelle is seen and a USG head is recommended, it reveals the presence of blood in the ventricle. Which of the following is the most important risk factor in the etiology of IVH in neonates?
questions.solution:
• All the options mentioned in the question are risk factors for IVH. However, the single most important factor is prematurity, with IVH being very uncommon in term babies
  • IVH occurs due to fragile, highly vascular collection of vessels near the lateral ventricle, known as germinal matrix

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presented to the office by his parents with a skin rash for 2 weeks. He was born out of a consanguineous marriage and had a history of the collodion membrane. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he had large, thick, plate-like brown scaling in a generalized distribution; no erythroderma and ectropion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lammellar ichthyosis

  • This patient’s signs and symptoms indicate Lamellar Ichthyosis (LI).
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease in which there is a deficiency of the transglutaminase-1 enzyme.
  • Large thick brown plate-like hyperkeratosis occurs as shown in the image below:

  • The scaling occurs over the whole body. In severe cases drooping of lower eyelids (ectropion), palmoplantar keratoderma, and scarring alopecia occurs.
  • The affected babies also have a history of collodion membrane at birth
ICHTHYOSIS VULGARIS X LINKED ICHTHYOSIS LAMELLAR ICHTHYOSIS
AD XLR AR
Def. of filaggrin Def. of steroid sulphatase enzyme Def. of transglutaminase-1 enzyme

Fine scales

Extensors mainly involved

Winter exacerbation

Thick brown hyperkeratosis

Flexors spared

Birth complications

Larger thick brown plate-like hyperkeratosis

The whole body involved' Collodion membrane/ baby

Option A: Ichthyosis Vulgaris​​​​​

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris occurs due to a deficiency of filaggrin.
  • The affected patient has a long-lasting history of fine fish-like scales affecting extensor surfaces.

Option C: X Linked Ichthyosis

  • Linked Ichthyosis is an X-linked recessive disease caused by the deficiency of steroid sulphatase enzyme.
  • Flexor areas are spared.

Option D: Netherton syndrome

  • Newborns have skin that is red and scaly (ichthyosiform erythroderma).
  • Triad – ichthyosis, hair shaft abnormality, and severe atopic diathesis

questions.text: A Neonate during the 1st week of life found with excessive watering and ropy mucous discharge in the conjunctival sac. On examination, you found the involved structure which is depicted in this image. Which of the following describes correct about the Direction of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
• Nasolacrimal duct opens in anterior part of inferior meatus.
  • The direction of the nasolacrimal duct is Backwards (Inwards), laterally, and downwards (mnemonic: NLD).

It courses anterior to maxillary ostium

  • Opening of the nasolacrimal duct is guarded by Hasner’s mucosal valve

questions.text: Sandeep Singh, a 35 years old army personnel suddenly fall down while doing patrolling in the Thar desert border in Rajasthan. He was immediately taken to a Military hospital and assessed by a Medical officer. On examination - he was unconscious and unresponsive and his pulse was impalpable. ECG was done and a diagnosis of PEA (Pulseless Electrical Activity) was made. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The 5 H and 5 T of pulseless electrical activity → PEA implies that electrical activity is seen on ECG but the pulse is absent.
  • The leading cause of PEA is hypoxia secondary to respiratory failure (40-50% cases) and hypovolemia.
  • Hydrogen ion depletion implies alkalosis whereas PEA occurs with acidosis.

H

Hypovolemia

Hypoxia
Hydrogen Ion (acidosis)

Hypo / Hyperkalemia

Hypothermia

T

Toxins

Tamponade

Tension Pneumothorax

Thrombosis (heart: acute, massive MI)

Thrombosis (lungs: massive PEE)

questions.text: A 65-years-old uncontrolled diabetes patient came to your clinic with a complaint of otalgia, greenish discharge from the ear. Further examination helps you to diagnose the case as malignant otitis externa. Which of the following dehiscence in the external auditory canal leads to the spread of infection in this case?
questions.solution:
Malignant external otitis (MEO) is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone. The causative organism is usually Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in immune deficiency patients.

The infection begins as external otitis that progresses into osteomyelitis of the temporal bone( Lateral Skull base osteomyelitis).

Spread of the disease outside the external auditory canal occurs through the fissures of Santorini(two vertical fissures in the anterior portion of the cartilage of the external auditory meatus, filled by fibrous tissue)and the osseocartilaginous junction

Notch of Rivinus-It is a defect in the upper tympanic part of the temporal bone, filled by the upper portion of the tympanic membrane.

Petro-tympanic fissure-It is a fissure in the temporal bone that runs from the temporomandibular joint to the tympanic cavity.

Foramen of Huschke-It represents a developmental defect in the anteroinferior aspect of the bony external auditory meatus.

questions.text: A multigravida presents at term in active labor with good uterine contractions. On examination, the cervix is 5 cm dilated and the fetal head lies at 0 station, the occiput is placed posteriorly in the maternal pelvis. The most appropriate next step in management is

choices.text: Allow progress and watch for spontaneous rotation

questions.solution:
Out of total Occipito posterior position,

-80% becomes OccipitoAnterior-

  • Mode of delivery - Normal (hence it is preferable to wait and watch for spontaneous rotation to occur)

-15-16% becomes persistent OccipitoPosterior

  • Occurs in anthropoid pelvis
  • Mode of Delivery - Face to pubis delivery

-2-4% undergoes Deep transverse arrest

  • Occurs in android pelvis
  • Mode of delivery - Manual rotation and forceps extraction(sagittal suture of the baby should be in AP plane of the pelvis) or cesarean section

questions.text: A 55-years-old patient, Lakha Singh presented to OPD with complaints of weakness and fatigue, dyspnea on lying down and palpitations. Symptoms aggravate at night time when he tries to sleep at bed. He gives h/o of Rheumatic heart disease in past . O/E - BP = 116/ 80 mm Hg, Pulse = 86bpm , elevated JVP, Hyperdynamic Apex beat with apical thrill on palpation. ECHO was done which revealed Mitral regurgitation. A diagnosis of Chronic Mitral regurgitation was made. Which of following is false regarding Chronic Mitral Regurgitation?
questions.solution:
• Narrow split S1 is a feature of mitral Stenosis. Choice D is incorrect.
  • In case of Mitral Regurgitation, the extra blood that flows into left atrium has to come back to left ventricle during diastolic phase. This leads to mid diastolic murmur .Choice A is Correct.
  • Due to early A2, wide Split S2 is heard. Choice B is correct
  • The most characteristic auscultatory finding is grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur. Choice C is correct.

Chronic MR features

  • S1 = soft
  • S2 = Wide split = Early A2
  • S3++
  • S4++ = extreme LV dilatation
  • Opening snap = absent
  • Primary murmur = Pansystolic = Apex = High pitch = Radiating to Interscapular area or Axilla
  • Secondary murmur = severe MR = Mid-diastolic murmur

questions.text: A 35-year-old smoker received a 45% total burn surface area when he got caught up in a house fire. One-half of the burnt surface appears to be third degree. On the third post-burn day, the patient is noted to have bloody drainage from a nasogastric tube and a decrease of 5% in his hematocrit. The appropriate management should include which of the following?

choices.text: Urgent upper gastrointestinal contrast study to delineate site of bleeding
Immediate selective arteriography via the left gastric artery
Urgent esophagogastroduodenoscopy to diagnosis the cause of bleeding
Urgent intravenous infusion of vasopressin at 0.2–0.4 IU/min

questions.solution:
A patient with 45% total body surface area burn implies a major burn where there is volume depletion due to third space fluid losses leading to hypoperfusion of gastric mucosa which in turn leads to stress erosions and ulceration which may cause upper GI bleed.

Stress-related gastritis is characterized by the appearance of multiple superficial erosions of the entire stomach, most commonly in the body. It is due to acid and pepsin injury in the context of ischemia from hypoperfusion states. These lesions are different from the solitary ulcerations, relating to acid hypersecretion that can occur in patients with severe head injury ( Cushing ulcers).

Cushing described the appearance of acute peptic ulceration in patients with head trauma. When stress ulceration is associated with major burns, these lesions are referred to as Curling’s ulcers. In 1842, Curling described duodenal ulcer or duodenitis in burn patients.

Risk factors for the development of stress erosions

  • Multiple trauma
  • Head trauma
  • Major burns
  • Clotting abnormalities
  • Severe sepsis
  • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome
  • Cardiac bypass
  • Intracranial operations

Patient with clinical evidence of a GI bleed should receive endoscopy within 24 hours and while awaiting for it , they should be treated with a proton pump inhibitor

Endoscopic therapy is instituted if bleeding is active or when bleeding is stopped if there is a significant risk of rebleeding. Forrest classification to assess rebleed. Grade IA, Ib, IIa have a high risk of rebleed

Forrest class Endoscopic appearance
High risk
1a Active spurting bleeding
1b Active oozing bleeding
2a Non-Bleeding visible vessel
2b Adherent clot
Low risk
2c Pigmented clot
3 Clean base ulcer

In those who develop significant bleeding,acid-suppressive therapy is often successful in controlling hemorrhage. In rare cases when this fails, consideration should be given to the administration of vasopressin or octreotide, endoscopic therapy, or even angiographic embolization.

Identification and treatment of the source of bleeding are essential which can be achieved with endoscopy, angiography, or occasional laparotomy.

Endoscopic control of bleeding can be achieved with epinephrine, electrocoagulation, laser coagulation, heater probe, argon plasma coagulation, clip application, banding, etc.

Visceral angiography is indicated for patients who are actively bleeding or when endoscopy fails to control the bleeding. When an actively bleeding vessel is identified, embolization with gelatin sponge, autologous blood clot, coils often controls the bleeding.

Infusion of vasopressin may be used in patients with severe stress ulceration and ongoing bleed

The surgical choices included vagotomy and pyloroplasty with oversewing of the hemorrhage or near-total gastrectomy

Burns

Classification based on depth

First degree - injury localized to epidermis

Superficial second degree-injury to the epidermis and superficial dermis

Deep second degree - injury through the epidermis and deep into the dermis

Third degree-Full thickness injury through the epidermis and dermis into subcutaneous fat

Fourth degree - Injury through the skin and subcutaneous fat into underlying muscle or bone

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and lesions over the elbow and buttocks for the past 5 days. She states that her lesions are highly pruritic. On examination, vesiculo-papular lesions on the elbow and buttocks are seen. Duodenal biopsy shows complete villous atrophy. On histopathological examination, papillary tip micro abscess is present. An anti-Tissue transglutaminase antibody is detected. Which of the following is the best long-term treatment option for this patient?

choices.text: Gluten-free diet with minerals and vitamins

questions.solution:
Options A: Gluten-free diet with minerals and vitamins

This patient most likely has dermatitis herpetiformis due to underlying celiac disease. The best long-term management is avoidance of a gluten-containing diet.

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder.
  • The autoimmune attack is against gluten present in barley, rye, oat, and wheat.
  • The patient presents with chronic malabsorption diarrhea and skin manifestations.
  • Lesions are pruritic.
  • There are increased chances of T-cell lymphoma.
  • Associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8
  • Duodenal biopsy shows villus atrophy, intraepithelial lymphocytosis, and crypt hyperplasia.
  • Diagnosis is made by detecting antibodies against tissue transglutaminase, endomysium, or gliadin.
  • Treatment includes restrictions on a gluten-containing diet like BROW (Barley, Rye, Oat, Wheat)
  • Rice, Maize, and Millets can be given
  • For skin manifestations like dermatitis herpetiformis, dapsone and sulfonamides are used.

Option B: Dapsone

  • Dapsone is the drug of choice for acute symptomatic management.
  • Antibody persists, causing relapses
  • The best long-term management is avoidance of a gluten-containing diet.

Option C: Acyclovir

  • It is an antiviral drug that acts by inhibiting viral nucleic acid
  • This patient does not have a herpes infection.

Option D: Steroids

  • Steroids are not the treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • They are used for atopic and autoimmune diseases

questions.text: A 55-year old woman presented at the outpatients' clinic with right upper quadrant pain and abdominal distention. A year before she was diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma, stage IA, and underwent abdominal hysterectomy and removal of both ovaries. She had not received oral contraceptives in the past. On CECT, a Delayed homogenous Centripetal Contrast Enhancement pattern is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hemangiomas have initial peripheral nodular puddling of contrast with a delayed homogenous central enhancement pattern.

HCC has an early arterial enhancement and Rapid Washoutpattern (HCC supplied mainly by hepatic artery).

Multiphasic CT of Liver

Table showing enhancement pattern of different liver lesions:

Pre contrast Arterial Phase Portal venous phase Delayed
Hepatocellular Ca Low attenuation Homogenous enhancement Washout of lesion Isodense
Adenoma Low attenuation Homogenous enhancement 85% Iso or hypodense Iso or hypodense
Haemangioma Low attenuation Peripheral puddles Partial Fill in Complete fill in
FNH Iso/Low attenuation Homogenous enhancement Hypodense Isodense
Hypervascular Mets Low attenuation Homogenous enhancement Hypodense
Metastasis Low attenuation Hypodense Hypodense
Cyst Low attenuation No enhancement
Abscess LOW attenuation may have irregular margins Transient regional enhancement Ring enhancement

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to a gynecologist for a health check-up and Pap smear. She has two live children and does not desire more. On enquiring about contraception, she says that she is using this contraceptive pill which has to be consumed twice a week. TRUE about this contraceptive is :
questions.solution:
Centchroman/ Ormeloxifene

  • Nonsteroidal estrogen antagonist: SERM (Selective estrogen receptor modulator)
  • Developed at CDRI, Lucknow.
  • Tablets of 30 mg to be taken twice a week for 3 months and then once a week for contraception.
  • Has a weak Estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic effect—acting mostly on the endometrial target organs to suppress proliferation of the endometrium, thereby interfering with the nidation of the embryo;
  • Causes asynchrony between Ovulation and the endometrial development

Other uses: Breast cancer, benign breast diseases, abnormal uterine bleeding

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with no medical history presented to the emergency department complaining of severe pain of his left upper extremity. Eight hours prior to presentation, he sustained a fall in his backyard and noticed swelling over his left forearm with tolerable pain. On first examination, his left forearm was markedly swollen, with extension to the left shoulder. This case is suspected for Acute compartment syndrome, Fasciotomy is planned. All of the following structures are cut in fasciotomy except?
questions.solution:
Fasciotomy is an emergency procedure used to release pressure in compartment syndrome either due to trauma or infections.

Fasciotomy must release skin, superficial fascia and deep fascia.

questions.text: A patient’s lifestyle can lead to a sleep disturbance. We usually call this inadequate sleep hygiene. The focus of universal sleep hygiene is on modifiable environmental and lifestyle components that may interfere with sleep, as well as behaviors that may improve sleep.Which of the following is not the right advice, with respect to sleep hygiene?

choices.text: Wake up at the same time
30 mL and lesser amount of alcohol could be useful to induce sleep over long term
Use bed for sleep and sexual activity

questions.solution:
Some basic components of sleep hygiene are:

  • Regular, daily physical exercises (preferably not in the evening)
  • Minimize daytime napping ·Avoid fluid intake and heavy meals just before bedtime
  • Avoid caffeine intake (e.g. tea, coffee, cola drinks) before sleeping hours
  • Avoid regular use of alcohol (especially avoid use of alcohol as a hypnotic for promoting sleep)
  • Sleep in a dark, quiet, and comfortable environment
  • Regular times for going to sleep and waking-up Try relaxation techniques
  • Avoid using mobile or other electronic devices while on bed.
  • Avoid repeated sight towards clock to check time of sleep initiation.

HOW TO REMEMBER :

Fact is alcohol cause stupor and coma in high quantities but it disturbs sleep in small quantities and regular use.

questions.text: A patient came to Eye OPD with intense watering, pain and photophobia. She was a regular contact lens user and she forgot to remove contact lens in the night. On examination, there was an epithelial defect. What is the first line of treatment?
questions.solution:
• Patient presents with overnight use of contact lenses not intended for such use and symptoms suggestive of corneal involvement. Commonest complication with such use is development of corneal abrasion (epithelial defect) which can be potentially complicated by secondary corneal infections.
  • Corneal abrasions are potentially serious complications and must not be ignored. Such cases need to be carefully evaluated to rule out any corneal infiltrate and ensure no contact lens induced keratitis has set in.

Contact Lens Over-wear Syndrome:

Treatment

  1. Immediately Discontinue contact lens use*
  2. Frequent antibiotic eye drops or ointment use (preservative free) - 2 hourly - commonly used are tobramycin, Bacitracin/Polymxyin or newer Fluoroquinolones (Moxifloxacin)
  3. Follow up within 1 day or sooner if symptoms worsen
  4. Topical cycloplegics and Oral NSAID to relieve pain
  5. Patching is usually avoided so as to prevent Serious Pseudomonas infections which can develop overnight chances of which increase with patching
  6. Steroid eye drops are avoided as they can inhibit corneal epithelial repair mechanisms and thereby lead to non healing abrasions.

High yield fact:

  • Most common Organism in Contact Lens induced Keratitis: Pseudomonas
  • Most specific Organism for Contact Lens associated Keratitis: Acanthamoeba

questions.text: A 55-years-old male, Laxmikant Iyer presented to OPD with complaints of shortness of breath, swelling of legs, Fatigue, palpitations, dizziness, and episodes of fainting. He is a chronic alcoholic. Examination findings revealed a Dicrotic pulse on palpation and a Pansystolic murmur is heard on auscultation. ECHO was done and a diagnosis of DCMP was made. Following procedure was done as a part of treatment whose image is shown below. The procedure done is?
questions.solution:
• The image shows Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) device with three leads seen in the color blue.
  • The leads are touching the right atrium and right ventricular endocardial surface.
  • The third lead is seen on the left side of a vein and is stimulating the left side of the heart.
  • This strategy is useful for patients with dilated cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure where the right and left ventricles do not contract simultaneously but asynchronously.
  • Choice A, I.C.D is ruled out as it has two leads while this image has 3 leads.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient known case of type I diabetes mellitus came to the OPD with complaints of abdominal distension and puffiness of the face. He was found to have elevated urea and creatinine levels. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have end-stage renal disease. The patient was advised for the combined pancreas and kidney transplantation. Criteria for a pancreas donor include:

choices.text: No replaced hepatic artery vessels arising from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA)
Complications are less when compared tot other solid organs

questions.solution:
Donor selection for pancreatic transplantation

*Type I diabetes mellitus obviously is a contraindication. Relative contraindications include previous pancreatic procedures as well as pancreatic disorders, such as chronic pancreatitis and intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm. Hyperglycemia in itself is not a contraindication to pancreas procurement because its cause in brain dead donors usually is severe insulin resistance which is rarely observed in recipients

All three abdominal organs (pancreas, liver, and intestine) can be procured at the same time and transplanted into three different recipients

During pancreas procurement, a “no-touch” technique of the gland is preferred. The pancreas should not be extensively flushed at the end of the procurement

In case of a replaced or aberrant right hepatic artery, this first branch off of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is carefully dissected out from the posterior surface of the pancreas. Areplaced or aberrant right hepatic artery does not transverse the pancreas and is not a contraindication to combined pancreas and liver procurement

The most common technique to create a single arterial inflow to the pancreas graft is the “Y-graft” reconstruction, using a resected segment of the donor iliac artery bifurcation. Here the donor external iliac artery is anastomosed to the donor SMA and the donor internal iliac artery is anastomosed end-to-end to the splenic artery and the donor internal iliac artery is anastomosed to the splenic artery. This procedure allows the donor common iliac artery to be anastomosed as a single vessel to the recipient’s common iliac artery

Pancreatic transplants are performed in three recipient categories:

  • Simultaneous pancreas and kidney (SPK) transplant in diabetic and uremic patients
  • Pancreas after kidney (PAK) transplant in diabetic and post uremic patients
  • Pancreas transplant alone (PTA) in nonuremic patients with brittle diabetes mellitus

In addition, they can also be performed in patients who have undergone a total pancreatectomy for benign disease

Complications

The technical complication rate for pancreatic transplants is higher than for any other solid organ transplant. The most common surgical complications are thrombosis, intraabdominal abscesses, and bleeding. The most common nonsurgical complication post-transplant is rejection

questions.text: A 43-year-old male who was diagnosed to have peptic ulcer disease underwent subtotal gastrectomy with reconstruction as the patient failed to respond to medical therapy. Metabolic complications of subtotal gastrectomy with Billroth I or Billroth II reconstruction include:
questions.solution:
*Gastric surgery results in numerous disorders collectively called post gastrectomy syndromes

Dumping syndrome

Dumping syndrome can be early (20 to 30 minutes after eating) or late (2 to 3 hours after a meal)

Early dumping is more common, with more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects.GI symptoms include nausea and vomiting, a sense of epigastric fullness, cramping abdominal pain, and often explosive diarrhea. The cardiovascular symptoms include palpitations, tachycardia, diaphoresis, fainting, dizziness, flushing, and occasional blurred vision. Early dumping occurs because of the rapid passage of food of high osmolarity from the stomach into the small intestine. This induces a rapid shift of extracellular fluid into the intestinal lumen. This leads to hypovolemia and the resultant symptoms mentioned above.

In late dumping, when carbohydrates are delivered to the small intestine, they are quickly absorbed resulting in hyperglycemia which triggers the release of large amounts of insulin. This overcompensation results in profound hypoglycemia which in turn causes the release of catecholamines which results in diaphoresis, tremulousness, lightheadedness, tachycardia, and confusion

Treatment involves avoiding high carbohydrate foods, frequent small meals rich in protein and fat, and separating liquids and solids during a meal

-> Metabolic disturbances

Iron deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. The most common metabolic defect appearing after gastrectomy is anemia. Anemia is related to iron deficiency (more common) or impairment in vitamin B12 metabolism. More than 30% of patients undergoing gastrectomy have iron deficiency anemia. Patients undergoing subtotal gastrectomy require lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation Osteoporosis and osteomalacia occur due to deficiencies in calcium

Afferent loop syndrome

Due to partial obstruction of afferent limb, pancreatic and hepatobiliary secretions accumulate resulting in distension leading to epigastric discomfort and cramping. The intraluminal pressure increases leading to bilious vomiting and relief of symptoms. Treatment involves surgical correction. A long afferent limb is usually the underlying problem so treatment involves the elimination of this loop

Efferent loop obstruction

It is rare. Left upper abdominal colicky pain, bilious vomiting, and abdominal distension. The diagnosis is usually established by a GI contrast study. Operative intervention is almost always necessary

Alkaline reflux gastritis

Seen in patients who have undergone gastric resection with a Billroth II anastomosis. For patients with intractable symptoms, the surgical procedure of choice is the conversion of Billroth II anastomosis into a Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy in which the Roux limb has been lengthened to more than 40 cm

Gastric atony

Gastric emptying delayed after truncal and selective vagotomies as antral pump function is lost. There is a reduction in the ability to empty solids whereas emptying of liquids is accelerated because of loss of receptive relaxation of proximal stomach. Treatment involves prokinetic agents

Malignant transformation

Gastrectomy and drainage are independent risk factors for gastric cancer

questions.text: A female child of 4 years age goes to the Anganwadi, her caretaker says that she doesn't eat much nor is she that playful unlike other children and also that her height is constant from last 1.5 yr while other children of the same age are growing normally. At what rate should the height of children be increasing in the age group of 2-10 years?
questions.solution:
Age Length or height (cm)

Birth

6 months

1 year

2 years

3 years

4 years

50

65

75 (increases by 50%)

90

95

100 (Doubles)

Thereafter, the child gains about 6 cm in height every year, until the age of 12 years.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was admitted to the ward with complaints of fever for 2 weeks duration. After admission his fever pattern is recorded (shown below). In addition, he has arthritis and hepatosplenomegaly. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The depicted fever pattern is suggestive of Quotidian fever.

Quotidian fever means the presence of daily fever spikes with temperature touching and going below baseline (37ºC ) on occasions.

Among the given options, clinical history and this fever pattern are suggestive of Systemic onset JIA.

Systemic JIA (sJIA):

  • Usually begins as an intermittent fever with a characteristic twice-daily peak
  • Evanescent maculopapular truncal rash
  • Arthritis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Serositis (pericarditis or pleuritis)
  • Elevated ESR, Thrombocytosis
  • Rheumatoid factor - Negative

Other Options:

Measles: common in preschool children; fever, rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion, dry cough, Koplik spots on 2nd or 3rd day of illness, rash on the fourth day with rise in fever.

Enteric fever: The hallmark of enteric fever is fever which starts as a low-grade fever and then shows stepwise increase peaking to as high as 103-104°C by the end of the first week; fever is associated with malaise, anorexia, nausea; coated tongue, hepatosplenomegaly

Acute leukemia: Pallor, fatigue, petechiae, purpura or bleeding, infections, lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, bone pain, and tenderness

questions.text: A 65-years-old chronic smoker came to the hospital with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx. Biopsy revealed laryngeal carcinoma. You and your senior doctor planned for a total laryngectomy. Which of the following is best for the maintenance of the airway during laryngectomy?
questions.solution:
• Maintenance of airway during laryngectomy in a patient with carcinoma larynx is best done by Tracheostomy.
  • After tracheostomy laryngectomy is performed completely.
  • At the end of laryngectomy, a permanent stoma is created for the maintenance of the airway for the rest of the life.

questions.text: A 45-years-old chronic smoker came with a history of hoarseness, foreign body sensation for the last 6 months. 2 weeks back, the patient developed pain during swallowing. your ENT professor diagnosed it as laryngeal carcinoma and a total laryngectomy was done. Postoperative esophageal speech rehabilitation given. The dynamic component of phonation in an esophageal speech in laryngectomy lies at
questions.solution:
Comparison of speech production before and after laryngectomy
Physical requirements Normal laryngeal voice production Oesophageal speech production Surgical voice production
Initiator Moving column of air from the lungs Moving column of air from the esophagus Moving column of air from the lungs
Vibrator Vocal cords Vibratory /pharyngo-oesophageal (PE) segment Vibratory / pharyngo-oesophageal (PE) segment
Resonators Resonating cavities: nose, mouth, pharynx Resonating cavities; nose, mouth, pharynx Resonating cavities; nose, mouth pharynx

questions.text: A 50-year-old construction worker continues to have elevated BP of 160/100 mmHg after a third agent (thiazide) is added to his anti-hypertensive regimen. Physical examination is normal, electrolytes are normal and he is not taking any over the counter medications. Which is the next helpful step in the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient is suffering from resistant hypertension and the leading cause of resistant hypertension is non- compliance on the part of patient.
  • Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above goal in spite of the concurrent use of 3 antihypertensive agents of different classes. Ideally, one of the 3 agents should be a diuretic and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts.

questions.text: An intern was assisting a C-section for the first time during her rotation in the Obs-Gynecology department. A 30 yrs old multigravida gave birth to a large for-age baby, the curious intern asked the senior doctor, which factor prevents newborns to suffer from hypothermia?

choices.text: Larger head size compared to rest of the body

questions.solution:
• The presence of brown fat is a protective mechanism (non-shivering thermogenesis) against hypothermia in newborn babies
  • Infants have more body surface area as compared to adults which makes them prone to heat loss. In particular, head size has the largest body surface area in the entire body
  • In low birth weight and preterm infants, the insulating layer of subcutaneous fat is thin which also makes them prone to hypothermia

questions.text: A 56 years old female presented to the emergency with complain of breathlessness, chest pain, and sweating for 20 mins. The on-duty intern ordered ECG. ECG showed ST-segment depression and T wave inversion. His provisional diagnosis based on ECG and clinical picture was ?? NSTEMI or ?? Stable angina. Which is the best investigation he should order to differentiate between stable angina and NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
• Cardiac markers are used in the diagnosis and risk stratification of patients with chest pain and suspected acute coronary syndrome(ACS).
  • The cardiac troponins, in particular, have become the cardiac markers of choice in acute coronary syndrome which includes NSTEMI.
  • However, in chronic Stable angina, the symptoms arise on exertion/emotion or post-prandially and have characteristic ST-segment depression on exercise testing. Cardiac biomarkers are normal as no cell death occurs in this case.

questions.text: A woman is brought by her husband for an antenatal check-up at 14 weeks of pregnancy. She is a known case of bipolar disorder and has been on lithium treatment. Which of the following fetal anomalies may be seen in her?
questions.solution:
Lithium effect on pregnant women:

  • Lithium should not be used during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, because of possible teratogenicity.
  • It is known to cause Ebstein's anomaly, a cardiac abnormality.
  • It is characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, often resulting in severe tricuspid regurgitation and marked RA enlargement.

questions.text: A 25 yr pregnant woman with mitral valve area of 1.4 sq.cm presents at 6weeks of pregnancy to the OPD. She is on antiarrhythmic drugs. Presently, she is in NYHA2. She was diagnosed as a case of RHD with MS at 16yr age. What is the risk of maternal mortality?
questions.solution:
The risk of maternal mortality in this patient would be <1% since she will be categorized under low-risk (MS & NYHA class II)

Risk category

Cardiac disease

1) Low risk ( maternal mortality < 1%)

  • Septal defects
  • Mitral stenosis
  • NYHA class 1 & II
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Pulmonary tricuspid lesions

2) Moderate risk ( maternal mortality 5 -15%)

  • Mitral stenosis, NYHA class III & class IV
  • Marfan syndrome With normal aorta
  • Uncomplicated coarctation Of aorta
  • Uncorrected TOF
  • Prosthetic valves

3) High risk ( maternal mortality (25-50%)

  • Eisenmenger syndrome
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome with abnormal aorta
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic alcoholic man complains of a burning sensation in the mouth. On examination he has thickened, dry, smooth tongue with the absence of the filiform papillae. MCV is 100. Which of the following should be the first line of approach in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above-given scenario is likely a case of vitamin B12 deficiency. Hence estimation of Vitamin B12 levels should be the first step in management.

  • Its deficiency may cause a bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration (demyelination) of the cervical and thoracic posterior and lateral (pyramidal) tracts of the spinal cord.
  • Other clinical features include:
  • Anorexia → weight loss
  • Diarrhea or constipation.
  • Glossitis
  • Angular cheilosis
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • The anemia and low leukocyte count may predispose to infections, particularly of the respiratory and urinary tracts.

Glossitis

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented to the ER 5 hours following the animal attack (boar) to the right side of the chest. He was complaining of right-sided chest pain and breathing difficulty. On arrival, he was conscious; his vitals were: heart rate – 96/min, respiratory rate – 26/min, blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, and SPO2 –90% room air. Local examination revealed 8 × 3 cm muscle deep laceration in the right 4th and 5th intercostal space subcutaneous emphysema; breath sounds were diminished on the right side. Initial resuscitation of this patient is best done by administration of which of the following?

choices.text: 5% Dextrose in Water and 0.45% normal saline

questions.solution:
Lactated Ringer solution and normal saline are two crystalloid solutions most commonly used in the initial resuscitation of trauma patients. On recognizing the presence of shock, resuscitation is immediately initiated with 1 to 2 liters of warm crystalloid solution infused through two large-bore short peripheral intravenous catheters. Initial resuscitation is limited to keep systolic blood pressure around 80 to 90mmHg. This prevents renewed bleeding from recently clotted vessels

In large volumes, normal saline can cause hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, whereas lactated Ringer’s solution has been implicated as a cause of metabolic alkalosis when used for prolonged periods. Because lactate exists as a racemic mixture in solution and the D-isomer of lactate is a known neurotoxin, there are concerns that large volumes of lactated Ringer’s solution may result in encephalopathy. If LR is to be used, it should be the LR manufactured by Baxter, which currently makes LR with only the L(+)-lactate isomer and it does not contain the D(-)-lactate isomer

Both normal saline and LR are mostly permeable through the vascular membrane, but they are poorly retained in the vascular space. After a few hours, only 175 to 200 ml of a 1-liter solution remains in the intravascular space

There is no conclusive evidence that colloid solutions (albumin, plasma protein solution, or hydroxyethyl starch solution) improve the rate of resuscitation or eventual outcome

Crystalloids and their composition

Electrolyte Plasma 0.9% NaCl Ringer's lactate, Hartmann's
Sodium 140 154 131
Potassium 5 0 5
Chloride 100 154 111
Calcium 2.2 0 2
Magnesium 1 0 1
Bicarbonate 24 0 0
Lactate 1 0 29

Based on the initial response to fluid resuscitation, hypovolemic injured patients can be separated into three broad categories: responders, transient responders, and non-responders. Patients are classified as non-responders who have persistent hypotension despite aggressive resuscitation. For persistent hypotension, (SBP<90 mm Hg in an adult), the current trend is to activate a massive transfusion protocol in which red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, platelets (1:1:1) are administered early

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient came to the pre-anesthetic assessment clinic for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. History revealed that he had undergone laparotomy 5 years back and intraoperatively he had malignant hyperthermia and treated for the same. Further details came to know from the previous hospital records. The anesthetic agent suitable for this case is-
questions.solution:
Xenon is Non- teratogenic.

Option A: Xenon has a very low blood-gas solubility coefficient (0.115) and produces rapid induction of and emergence from anesthesia.

Option B: Xenon produces no greenhouse effect or ozone depletion and is environmentally safe as it is prepared from the fractional distillation of atmospheric air, unlike the other inhaled anesthetics.

Option D: Does not trigger malignant hyperthermia

Other advantages of xenon:

Stable, Chemically Inert -No metabolism and low toxicity, Nonexplosive, Non-pungent, odorless Cardioprotective- It produces minimal cardiovascular depression, and it is not arrhythmogenic.

Has potent hypnotic and Analgesic activity - reduces intraoperative opioid requirements Neuroprotective without psychomimetic behavioral changes

Disadvantages of Xenon

  • High cost
  • Nausea, Vomiting
  • Xenon gas has a very high density (5.9 g/L) resulting in increased flow resistance and work of breathing. Thus, it may be a poor choice for patients with compromised respiratory function
  • Succinylcholine and all halogenated volatile anesthetics trigger malignant hyperthermia. So it should be avoided.

questions.text: A 56-years-old patient presented to the emergency with complaints of breathlessness, chest pain and drowsiness. He is a k/c/o lung cancer. Examination shows engorged and distended neck veins and low BP, soft S1 and S2. Which of the following is incorrect in this case scenario?
questions.solution:
Lung cancer can exhibit metastasis to heart→ Pericardial effusion.

CARDIAC TAMPONADE

The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade.

CAUSES

The most common causes of tamponade are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to neoplastic disease, tuberculosis, or bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection, cardiac operation, trauma, and treatment with anticoagulants

CLINICAL FEATURES

The three principal features of tamponade (Beck’s triad) are

1.Hypotension,
2.Soft or absent heart sounds, and
3.Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent.

The quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 mL when the fluid develops rapidly to as much as >2000 mL in slowly developing effusions when the pericardium has had the opportunity to stretch and adapt to an increasing volume.

CLINICAL SUSPICION

A high index of suspicion for cardiac tamponade is required because in many instances, no obvious cause for pericardial disease is apparent, and this diagnosis should be considered in any patient with otherwise unexplained sudden enlargement of the cardiac silhouette, hypotension, and elevation of jugular venous pressure.

ECG

There also may be reductions in amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves should raise the suspicion of cardiac tamponade.

Paradoxical Pulse 

This important clue to the presence of cardiac tamponade consists of a greater than normal (10 mmHg) inspiratory decline in systolic arterial pressure. When severe, it may be detected by palpating weakness or even disappearance of the arterial pulse during inspiration, but usually sphygmomanometric measurement of systolic pressure during slow respiration is required.

Blood Pressure

Because both ventricles share a tight incompressible covering, i.e.the pericardial sac, the inspiratory enlargement of the right ventricle causes leftward bulging of the interventricular septum, compresses and reduces left ventricular volume; stroke volume, and arterial systolic pressure.

questions.text: A primigravida presents with leaking per vaginum, for 12 hours at 34 weeks. She is admitted and induced for labor. However, after 6 hours, she develops fever and foul-smelling liquor discharge. Her TLC is 18,500. She is taken up for emergency LSCS and the baby is shifted to the nursery. The baby's umbilical cord has some purulent discharge without any surrounding erythema, swelling or tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
*Findings of prolonged leaking, complicating with fever, foul-smelling liquor, raised TLC are suggestive of chorioamnionitis.

An inflammation of the umbilical cord, sparing the stump and surrounding abdominal wall, in response to maternal chorioamnionitis, is called funisitis

FUNISITIS

  • Inflammation of the connective tissue of the umbilical cord
  • Occurs with chorioamnionitis
  • Fetal inflammatory response to intra-amniotic infection : funisitis + chorionic vasculitis
  • Involves only external cord surface and Wharton's jelly
  • Umbilical vessels are not involved
  • Does not involve the surrounding abdominal wall (involved in omphalitis)
  • Associated with increased fetal morbidity

questions.text: A young female patient presented with the complaints of blurring of vision, diplopia and photophobia for last three months . She told to the doctor that she changed the glasses ten times last year . On further examination ,the doctor noticed that there is conical protrusion of the cornea with central thinning and the apex of the cone is usually directed inferonasally. Which of the following is incorrect aboutthis condition ?

choices.text: Earliest clinical sign is Scissor reflex on retinoscopy
Bow tie pattern on corneal topography

questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Keratoconus.It usually associated with irregular astigmatism.

KERATOCONUS

  • Non -Inflammatory corneal ectasia characterized by central/paracentral corneal thinning
  • Young male with constantly changing power of spectacles with myopia & high cylinder

    SIGNS IN KERATOCONUS
  • Scissor reflex on retinoscopy (Earliest Clinical Sign)
  • Munson sign - notching of lower lid due to the corneal bulge noticed in downgaze
  • Enlarged corneal nerves
  • Oil droplet reflex - central area of corneal bulge visible in retro-illumination as an oil droplet against an illuminated retinal glow during slit lamp examination or on retinoscopy
  • Rizutti sign - light is shown from the temporal side (as in examining the anterior chamber depth), due to the conical shape of the cornea the light is focused at a point on the nasal limbus giving the light an arrow shaped reflex
  • Acute Hydrops - aqueous accumulated in stroma due to micro breaks in the corneal endothelium due to progressive corneal thinning. Cause of sudden painful defective vision with keratoconus
  • Fleischer ring - Partial or complete iron deposition ring in deep epithelium encircling the base of the cone in keratoconus. Characteristic in eyes with keratoconus.
  • Vogt's Striae - vertically oriented deep stromal lines (pre-Descemet's level) indicating corneal thinning and weakening which disappear on corneal pressure

Keratometry

  • Steep cornea
  • Irregular corneal astigmatism
  • Bow tie pattern

Corneal Pachymetry

  • Paracentral thinning of cornea

Investigation of Choice

  • Pentacam (automated corneal topography)

Important Associations of Keratoconus

  • Marfans
  • Leber congenital amaurosis
  • Vernal kerato conjunctivitis
  • Down’s syndrome
  • Atopy
  • Floppy eyelid syndrome
  • Ehler Danlos
  • Achondroplasia
  • Alagille syndrome
  • Apert syndrome

questions.text: A 50-year-old obese woman presents to the clinic with skin-colored lesions on her neck. Based on the image, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acrochordon or a skin tag is a common benign lesion composed of loose fibrous tissue and occurring mainly on the neck and major flexures as a small soft pedunculated protrusion. These lesions are very common, particularly in women at the menopause or later. They are frequently found together with seborrhoeic keratoses. The most common site is on the sides of the neck.


Treatment : Both cautery and cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen are effective.

questions.text: The PANIC DISORDER SEVERITY SCALE (PDSS) was developed in the 1990s as a brief rating scale for the severity of panic disorder. It has seven items, each of which is rated on an item-specific, 5-point Likert scale. Which of the following is not asked in this scale ?
questions.solution:
*Flashbacks are not characteristic of panic disorder, they are characteristic of PTSD.

The essential features of a panic disorder include presence for at least one month duration of recurrent attacks of severe anxiety which are not restricted to any particular situation or a set of circumstances and are unpredictable. depersonalisation and derealisation are common. If occurred in a situation, patient may avoid the situation in future. It is followed by preoccupation with fear of getting another attack.

Agoraphobia commonly co-occurs with panic disorder. Panic attacks can be seen in Phobias, panic disorder, major depressive disorder, PTSD.

ICD-10 :For a definite diagnosis, several severe attacks of autonomic anxiety should have occurred within a period of about 1 month:

1.in circumstances where there is no objective danger;

2.without being confined to known or predictable situations; and

3.with comparative freedom from anxiety symptoms between attacks (although anticipatory anxiety is common).

NOTE:Panic disorder should be the main diagnosis only in the absence of any of the phobias ; panic attacks are different from panic disorder.

questions.text: A 30-year-old women presented with history of nyctalopia and constriction of visual field of the left eye. On fundus examination, a pale optic disc, narrowed arterioles and extensive proliferations of the pigment epithelium in form of bone spicules in the periphery could be seen. The doctor made the diagnosis of retinitis pigmentosa. Which of the following is not associated with the above diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Remember RP associations by mnemonic LUCHR.

  • Lawrence-Moon-Beidel Syndrome
  • Usher Syndrome
  • Cockayne Syndrome
  • Hallgren Syndrome
  • Refsum Syndrome

Other associations:NARP, Abetalipoproteinemia

*Retinitis Pigmentosa is not associated with Hallervorden Spatz Syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with primary infertility is under evaluation for the presence or absence of ovulation. On days 9 and 11, a transvaginal scan shows no developing follicle. The action of which of the following endogenous hormones appears deficient in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
• Stimulation of the ovary in the early follicular phase is by FSH, as the growth and differentiation of primordial follicles are under the control of FSH.
  • The presence of FSH prevents follicles from undergoing Atresia.
  • Stimulation of the ovary in the later follicular phase is predominantly by FSH but also LH is required in the later follicular stage for the final maturity of the follicle before rupture.

FSH function

  • Selection of cohort of follicles every month
  • Selection and growth of dominant follicles
  • Have a role in Ovulation
  • FSH causes the breakdown of collagen & release of Ovum

LH functions

  • Ovulation(Main function)
  • Formation and maintenance of Corpus luteum
  • Final growth of follicles
  • Resumption of Arrested Meiosis

questions.text: Several types of gastrointestinal autografts have been used for the reconstruction of the esophagus following esophagectomy for esophageal carcinoma. Most successful reconstructions have been achieved by which of the following autograft?
questions.solution:
Ideally, the conduit substituting for the esophagus should mimic as closely as possible to the normal esophagus to preserve the quality of life

The conduit of choice for the esophagus is in the order of Stomach>colon>jejunum

Stomach

Today stomach is by far the most preferred conduit for replacing the esophagus in over 95% of cases. It is the quickest and simplest organ surgery for reconstruction. It has a robust arterial and venous supply and submucosal plexus. There is only the need for a single anastomosis. As the stomach is flexible, it can easily reach the neck for cervical or even hypopharyngeal anastomoses. Its main disadvantage is the potential of reflux and related aspiration problems. After mobilization, the stomach will receive its blood supply from the right gastroepiploic artery

Colon

It is the second option substitute when the stomach cannot be used or when the stomach has to be respected for oncological reasons. The main advantage of the colon is its versatility. The length is freely available for replacement of the entire esophagus up to the pharynx. The blood supply is from the left colic artery and the presence of a marginal artery, the artery of Drummond permits a linear transposition procedure without redundancy or mechanical kinking. It requires three anastomoses and thus longer operative time and higher rates of necrosis, morbidity, and mortality. Its use is contraindicated in the presence of an aortic aneurysm or extensive atherosclerotic disease involving superior mesenteric artery, previous colon surgery, inflammatory bowel disease, or tumors

Jejunum

It is the third most commonly used modality for esophageal reconstruction. It has a segmental vascular configuration making it more difficult to prepare a long segment putting it at a higher risk for ischemia and necrosis. It can be used as an interposition, a Roux-en-Y loop, or a free vascular graft

questions.text: A woman presents at 10 weeks for routine antenatal evaluation. The ultrasound at this gestation aims at localization of fetus and viability, however, only a few anomalies can be made out. Which one of the following congenital malformations of the fetus can be diagnosed at this gestation?
questions.solution:
• Ultrasound done in the first trimester helps in dating the pregnancy.
  • Malformations are best looked for at 18–20 weeks of gestation. If there is a malformation that is not viable with a normal life, then a decision to do a termination of pregnancy can be taken at this time ( In India: MTP only ≤ 20 weeks)
  • However, in the first trimester, i.e., around 9–11 weeks, gross malformations of the fetus like anencephaly, Acrania, or Spina Bifida can be picked up.
  • To detect specific deformities like holoprosencephaly or microcephaly, USG is to be done at 18–20 weeks of gestation and not in the first trimester.

Routine first-trimester USG is done for

  • Pregnancy dating
  • Fetal viability
  • Intrauterine or extrauterine
  • Multiple gestations
  • Nuchal translucency and nasal bone are checked at 11-13 weeks (markers for downs syndrome)

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to hospital with the malar flush. He is a k/c/o of a valvular heart disease and the doctor has planned a procedure for the valvular disorder. Below shown procedure was done. Which of following is the Valvular lesion being repaired in this 20-year-old man ?
questions.solution:
• Image shows a balloon valvotomy procedure being performed which rules out regurgitation lesions as valvotomy is performed in stenosis. Malar flush is already mentioned here which points towards mitral facies.
  • AS is ruled out since percutaneous aortic balloon valvuloplasty is preferred in children with AS. It is not used in adults with severe calcific AS because of high stenosis rates and procedural complications like embolic stroke.
  • MS with surface area <1 square cm/m2 (or) <1.5 square cm/m2in adults is treated with percutaneous mitral balloon valvotomy.

questions.text: A woman at 34 weeks of pregnancy presents for routine evaluation. The obstetrician examines her and finds the fundal height corresponding to 30 weeks. She advises an ultrasound to rule out IUGR. The best fetal parameter to diagnose IUGR in the fetus is:-
questions.solution:
• Estimation of IUGR is frequently made by the ratio of Head to abdominal circumference HC/AC ratio.
  • This ratio compares the most preserved organ in the malnourished fetus, the brain, represented by the circumference of the fetal head, with the most compromised organ, the liver, represented by the fetal AC.
  • Head circumference is last to be affected. Since the liver is the first organ be affected in IUGR babies, the abdominal circumference will be the first parameter to be compromised in growth restriction
  • The femur to abdomen ratio (FL/AC) remains constant after 20 weeks. The normal value for this index is 22 +/- 2. An upper limit of 23.5 (90th percentile) strongly suggests the diagnosis of FGR
  • HC/AC ratio: This ratio compares the most preserved organ in the malnourished fetus, the brain, represented by the circumference of the fetal head, with the most compromised organ, the liver, represented by the fetal AC. This measurement is of significant value in identifying FGR babies with asymmetric head to abdomen measurements.
  • Pathological restriction of fetal growth is usually present when the H/A ratio is above the 95th percentile for gestational age.
  • The Fetal Ponderel Index (FPI) is gestational age-independent and has a constant value throughout the second part of the pregnancy. The FPI is obtained by dividing the estimated fetal weight by the third power of the FL and its normal value is 8.325 ?+/- 2.5 (2 SD). An FPI of 7.0 or less should be considered abnormal and suggestive of PFGR.

Type I or symmetric FGR corresponds to fetuses that are symmetrically small and have normal HC/AC and FL/AC ratios. Early-onset, congenital anomalies, chromosomal defects, Poor prognosis

Type II or asymmetric FGR corresponds to fetuses that have an AC that is smaller than the HC and the FL resulting in abnormally high H/A and F/A ratios. Late-onset, diseases like PIH, good prognosis

Type III or intermediate FGR corresponds to fetuses that are initially symmetric but become asymmetric later in the pregnancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who was a case of polytrauma due to road traffic accident came to casualty. On examination, blood pressure was not recordable, carotid pulse was not felt and immediately cardiopulmonary resuscitation started according to ACLS guidelines. The monitor showed pulseless electrical activity. Not a reason behind this in this patient could be-
questions.solution:
The above clinical history & features are suggestive of Pulseless Electrical Activity (PEA).

*Pulseless ventricular tachycardia is not a cause of PEA.

Pulseless electrical activity(PEA) refers to the presence of organized electrical activity without a palpable pulse.

Mnemonic to remember the reversible causes of pulseless electrical activity is:

  • MAD (triple H) CAT

Mnemonic

  • M:massive pulmonary/coronary embolism
  • A:acidosis
  • D:drug overdose(digitalis,beta blockers,calcium channel blockers,tricyclic antidepressants,toxins)
  • H:hypoxia/hypothermia
  • H:hypovolaemia
  • H:hypokalaemia/hyperkalaemia
  • C:cardiac tamponade
  • A:acute myocardial infarction
  • T:tension pneumothorax

Prompt initiation of chest compressions and administration of 1mg epinephrine are recommended as temporary measures until the definitive therapy can be provided once the cause for PEA is identified. Asystole or ventricular fibrillation can develop if PEA untreated.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child complains of pain and swelling of the right tibia. On laboratory evaluation, he has elevated ESR and leucocytosis. X-ray shows a tibial lesion. Which of the following is the best investigation which can help us clinch the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Diagnostic is always Tissue Diagnosis (Biopsy).

→Tumors and infection can mimic each other (clinically and radiologically), e.g. Osteosarcoma and Ewings sarcoma are two tumors that mimic osteomyelitis. (Both have accompanying fever and increased local temperature).

→Tumors and bone infections are usually metaphyseal and both need tissue diagnosis for differentiation. Thus, Culture is gold standard for infection

→Histopathology is gold standard for tumors

·So rule is Culture all biopsies, biopsy all cultures.

In practice, both culture as well biopsy is taken of such lesion.

Culture: will only be helpful if it is an infective lesion by giving us the causative organism as well as susceptible antibiotic.

Biopsy: It will diagnose both tumor as well as infective lesion. Thus is the single investigation which can help in clinching the diagnosis in both the circumstances.

questions.text: Mechanoreceptors are a type of somatosensory receptors which relay extracellular stimulus to intracellular signal transduction through mechanically gated ion channels. Which of the following receptors are found in the dermis of the glabrous skin?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pacinian corpuscles

  • Mechanoreceptors are an important class of receptors of the somatosensory system. There are four types of mechanoreceptors in human skin: Merkel's disks, Ruffini endings, Meissner's corpuscles, and Pacinian corpuscle.
  • Meissner’s corpuscles (Tactile corpuscles) are a type of mechanoreceptor responsible for sensitivity to light touch and are primarily located in glabrous skin just beneath the epidermis within the dermal papillae.
  • Ruffini endings are localized deep in the dermis and are morphologically similar to the Golgi tendon organ, a large and thin spindle-shaped cylinder composed of layers of perineural tissue.
  • Pacinian corpuscles are located in the dermis of glabrous skin.
  • Merkel cell-neurite complex is located in the basal layer of the epidermis. It consists of clusters of Merkel cells making synapse-like associations with enlarged nerve terminals branching from a single nerve fiber.
Type of Mechanoreceptor Location Adaptation Sensation Encoded
Pacinian corpuscle
Meissner's corpuscle
Hair follicles
Ruffini's corpuscle
Merkel's receptors
Tactile discs		 Subcutaneous; intramuscular
Nonhairy skin
Hairy skin
Hairy skin
Nonhairy skin
Hairy skin

Very rapidly

Rapidly

Rapidly

Slowly

Slowly

Slowly

Vibration, tapping
Point discrimination, tapping, flutter

Velocity, direction of movement

Stretch, joint rotation

Vertical indentation of skin

Vertical indentation of skin

Option A: Meissner corpuscles

  • These are present in dermal papillae, not in basal layers.

Option C: Ruffini endings

  • These are present in the deep dermis, not dermal papillae.

Option D: Merkel cell-neurite complex

  • These are located in the basal layer of the epidermis.

questions.text: A child, 7 years old, is admitted to the hospital as he is suffering from marasmus. His chart for the measurement of weight and mid-arm circumference is maintained on a daily basis in order to keep a check if the child is responding to the treatment or not. Out of all the following devices, which device is not used to measure the mid-arm circumference of the child?
questions.solution:
Harpenden caliper is used to measure skinfold thickness which is an indication of subcutaneous fat.

The other three are used to measure the mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Shakir's tape is used to measure mid-upper arm circumference. It has three colored zones corresponding to various levels of wasting·
  • In bangle test, a bangle with an internal diameter of 4 cm is passed above the elbow. In severe malnutrition, it can be passed above the elbow, while in normal children it cannot.
  • QUAC stick - Quaker arm circumference measuring stick. It is a measure of expected Mid-arm circumference that would be expected for a given height.

questions.text: A 70-year old hypertensive patient presented to OPD with complaints of sudden onset of palpitations, dizziness, and loss of consciousness. On examination, his heart rate is 72 BPM and BP was 150/100. ECG was done which shows the following findings. Likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• ECG in lead II and other inferior leads show the presence of flutter waves( Sawtooth pattern).
  • 3-4 flutter waves before every narrow QRS complex.
  • Since the ventricular rateis75 bpm(RR interval), the atrial rate shall be obtained by multiplying the ventricular rate by 4 which is 300 bpm
  • The presence of risk factors of hypertension also gives clue to the diagnosis of atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 36-year-old G2P1L1 presents at bleeding PV at 20 weeks. On examination, the uterus is 26 weeks in size. Ultrasound shows the absence of a fetus, and the presence of heterogeneous uterine content appearing like a snowstorm. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
• History is suggestive of a complete mole (uterine size > POG, snowstorm appearance, and absence of fetus)
  • Suction evacuation is the treatment of choice for hydatidiform mole, regardless of uterine size. Follow this, with a gentle curettage.

Management of vesicular mole/complete mole

  • Suction evacuation (also do a gentle curettage with a sharp curette)
  • Do USG after a week to rule out retained bits
  • Do CXR to rule out metastasis
  • HCG follow up β-HCG estimation weekly till negative:

Values come to negative by

  • 9 Weeks in a Complete mole
  • 7 Weeks in an incomplete mole

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents to the gynecologist with complaints of heavy menstrual cycles and does not wish to take injections or daily tablets. She insists on a hysterectomy but the doctor advises her otherwise. The doctor then recommends this intrauterine device that can help her with her menstrual problems and also provide effective contraception but should be changed every 5 years. Which of the following is the CORRECT statement about this device?

choices.text: Releases 52 mg of progesterone every day

questions.solution:
The device discussed here is Mirena (LNG IUD system)

  • Contains 52 mg of Progesterone
  • 20mcg of progesterone released per day
  • Can be used for up to 5 years

Health benefits of Mirena include:

  1. Reduction of blood loss, which benefits patients with anemia and dysfunctional uterine bleeding
  2. Reduction of pain and dysmenorrhea in endometriosis and adenomyosis
  3. Beneficial effect on fibroids
  4. Does not influence lactation or affect infant growth and development.
  5. Can be used in the prevention and treatment of endometrial hyperplasia.
  6. Decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.
  7. Decreases the risk of PID and hence protects against ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 65-years-old male came to your clinic with complaints of Sensorineural hearing loss associated with vertigo and tinnitus. To rule out labyrinthitis, you are thinking of doing the Fitzgerald hall pike test. Which of the following is stimulated by this test?
questions.solution:
CALORIC TESTS

  • The principle of the caloric test is that changes in temperature in the external auditory canal influence the level of activity of the vestibular labyrinth.

How to perform

In order to obtain a satisfactory nystagmic response, the subject has to lie down with the head raised 30 degrees above horizontal. This places the lateral semicircular canal in an approximately vertical position; the more lateral position of this canal leaves it more accessible to external temperature changes.

  • The caloric test stimulates the lateral semicircular canal, the bulge of which is present on the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • Water irrigation at 30°C and 44°C (37 ± 7°C) is the standard technique.\
  • Each irrigation should last for 40 sec. ·
  • RESULTS: Cold irrigation induces horizontal nystagmus beating in the opposite direction of irrigation, and ipsilaterally during warm irrigation (cold-opposite-warm-same (COWS).

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, sexually active with multiple sexual partners, and an IV drug abuser, presents to the STD clinic with complaints of vaginal discharge. NAAT test confirms gonococcal cervicitis. She also has a history of recurrent urinary burning and frequency. All of the following factors from her history are risk factors for her present condition, EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Risk Factors of Gonococcal carriage and potential upper reproductive tract infection that merit screening are:

  • Age ≤ 24 years,
  • Prior or current STDs,
  • New or multiple sexual partners,
  • A partner with other concurrent partners,
  • A partner with an STD,
  • Lack of barrier protection in those without a monogamous relationship,
  • Commercial sex worker,
  • Drug abuse.

questions.text:
During the treatment of septic shock, a 28-year-old male remains hypotensive despite adequate volume replacement; PA occlusion pressure is 18 mm Hg. When dopamine is started, ventricular tachycardia develops and this is unresponsive to lidocaine. The V-tach converts back to sinus rhythm once the dopamine is stopped.
At this point, which of the following treatment is most appropriate for this hypotensive patient?
questions.solution:
Catecholamines are the vasopressors used most often for the treatment of septic shock with norepinephrine being the first-line agent followed by epinephrine

In this case, dopamine given has caused ventricular tachycardia due to its action on β1receptor

The patient is hypotensive and hence amrinone and dobutamine cannot be given as they both decrease the peripheral vascular resistance and cause a further decrease in blood pressure

Similar to dopamine, epinephrine is associated with severe arrhythmias this is due to increased myocardial workload and oxygen demand and hence this also cannot be given Phenylephrine is a selective α1agonist and hence is a potent vasoconstrictor. Phenylephrine and hence can be used in the treatment of septic shock in this case

Vasodilatory or septic shock is the result of dysfunction of the endothelium and vasculature secondary to circulating inflammatory mediators and cells or as a response to prolonged and severe hypoperfusion. It is characterized by peripheral vasodilation with resultant hypotension and resistant to treatment with vasopressors

Dobutamineprimarily stimulates cardiac β1receptors to increase cardiac output but may also vasodilate peripheral vascular beds, lower total peripheral resistance, and lower systemic blood pressure through effects on β2receptors. Hence adequate preload and intravascular volume is essential before administering dobutamine

Dopamine stimulates receptorsα1(vasoconstriction),β1receptors (cardiac stimulation), and β2receptors (vasodilation) with its effects on β receptors predominating at lower doses. Thus at normally employed doses, it raises cardiac output and systolic blood pressure with little effect on diastolic blood pressure. It may cause ventricular tachycardia, arrhythmia, and increased peripheral resistance

Phosphodiesterase inhibitors like amrinone and milrinone are not adrenergic agonist but they behave similar to dobutamine and increase contractility but also promote vasodilation resulting in hypotension and significant arrhythmia

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with loss of consciousness. He regains consciousness in the ER, and GCS on admission is 12/15. CNS examination is normal and auscultation reveals a narrow split S2 and clear lungs. ECG was done. Diagnosis is?

choices.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage with T wave inversion

questions.solution:
The ECG shows a heart rate of 60/min with left axis deviation

SV1+RV5> 35 mm is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy(SV1 = 20mm and RV5= 30mm)

*Narrow split S2 indicates outflow tract obstruction

Taking into consideration the age, the patient either suffers from HOCM or valvular aortic stenosis. The low cardiac output can lead to exertional syncope.

RIGHT OUTFLOW TRACT OBSTRUCTION → RVH → R wave more than 7mm in V1=R ≥ S wave=right axis deviation

Atrial Fibrillation → Irregularly irregular rhythm, Absent P waves (replaced by fibrillating f wave), Baseline vibration

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who is a chronic smoker and a known case of bronchiectasis posted for right pneumonectomy under general anesthesia with one lung ventilation. The patient was intubated with double lumen tube and confirmation of the right placement of the tube done with fibreoptic bronchoscopy. Then the patient positioned in the left lateral position for surgery of the right lung. Pulmonary changes occur in this patient is-

choices.text: Dependent lung is relatively over ventilated and over-perfused
Dependent lung is relatively over ventilated and under-perfused
Dependent lung is relatively under ventilated and over-perfused
Dependent lung is relatively under ventilated and under-perfused

questions.solution:
Anaesthetized patient who is on lateral decubitus position : preferred for pulmonary surgery and one lung ventilation

Dependent lung is relatively under-ventilated and over-perfused

Non-dependent lung is over-ventilated and under-perfused.

In a patient who is mechanically ventilated ,the combination of the lateral weight of the mediastinum and the disproportionate cephalad pressure of abdominal contents on the dependent lung favours overventilation of the nondependent lung .At the same time, the effect of gravity causes the pulmonary blood flow to the under ventilated dependent lung to increase. So that ventilation perfusion matching worsens potentially affecting the gas exchange and ventilation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with an ulcerated lesion on his right lateral leg for several weeks (given in the image below). He occasionally has to cramp in his calf when walking. His dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are not palpable. The ulcer has a punched-out edge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here, an old age man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia is more prone to atherosclerosis and hence peripheral vascular disease. He also has occasional cramping during walking which signifies intermittent claudication which is pathognomic and also there is an absence of peripheral pulsation which indicates a case of peripheral vascular disease which has lead to punched out ulcer formation due to ischemia

Ischemic/Arterial ulcers

These wounds occur due to a lack of blood supply and are typically extremely painful in patients with pure ischemic ulcers. They usually are associated with other symptoms of peripheral vascular disease, such as the history of intermittent claudication, rest pain, and color or trophic changes. These wounds commonly are present at the most distal portions of the extremities such as the interdigital clefts, although more proximal locations are also encountered. On examination, there may be diminished or absent pulses with decreased ankle-brachial index and poor formation of granulation tissue. Other signs of peripheral ischemia such as dryness of skin, hair loss, scaling and pallor can be present. The wound itself is shallow with smooth margins, punched out the edge and a pale base, and surrounding skin may be present

Venous stasis ulcers

Venous ulcers commonly occur in the Gaiter’s area(area between the medial malleolus and tendon Achilles). They have sloping edges and the floor is filled with healthy granulation tissue. They are due to venous stasis and increased venous pressure. On the microvascular level, there is alteration and distension of dermal capillaries with leakage of fibrinogen which polymerizes and leads to perivascular cuffing that can impede oxygen exchange contributing to ulceration(fibrin cuff theory). Another hypothesis is that neutrophils adhere to the capillary endothelium and cause plugging with diminished dermal blood flow leading to ulceration(white cell trapping theory). There occurs extravasation of hemoglobin which breaks down causing pruritus and skin damage. The resulting brownish pigmentation of skin and loss of subcutaneous fat produces lipodermatosclerosis. The cornerstone of treatment of venous ulcer is compression therapy

Diabetic ulcer

The major contributors to the formation of diabetic ulcers include sensory and motor neuropathy, foot deformity and ischemia. The treatment involves local wound management and diabetic control

Decubitus or pressure ulcer

A pressure ulcer is a localized area of tissue necrosis that develops when soft tissue is compressed between a bony prominence and external surface. Pressure ulcer formation is accelerated in the presence of friction, shear force and moisture. The four stages of pressure ulcer formation are:

Stage I- no blanching erythema of intact skin

Stage II- partial thickness skin loss involving epidermis or dermis or both

Stage III- full-thickness skin loss but not through the fascia

Stage IV- full-thickness skin loss with extensive involvement of muscle and bone

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presented to the OPD with complaints of swelling in front of the neck. FNAC revealed a papillary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following statements regarding papillary thyroid carcinoma are true?

Papillary thyroid carcinomas less than 1 cm in diameter are microcarcinomas
70 to 80% of thyroid carcinomas diagnosed are papillary thyroid carcinoma
Microscopic evidence of multicentric disease is present in 70% of cases
The most important risk factor for PTC is childhood radiation
questions.solution:
All statements are true.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma(PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy and usually is associated with an excellent prognosis particularly in young patients

Of thyroid carcinomas diagnosed, 70 to 80% are PTC

The most important risk factor for PTC is childhood radiation

PTC occurs in a 2.5:1 female to male ratio and the peak incidence occurs between ages 30 and 50 years

PTC most typically manifests either as a palpable thyroid nodule or as an incidental imaging finding

Occasionally a metastatic PTC manifests as a painless lateral neck mass that is clinically detected before detecting the primary thyroid lesion called lateral aberrant thyroid

Prognostic risk classification for PTC include the AGES and AMES scoring systems

Age at diagnosis is the most important prognostic factor and diagnosis at a younger age is associated with excellent survival

The absence of distant metastasis at the time of initial treatment and size less than 4cm are other important positive predictors

Multicentricity can be anticipated in 70% of patients with PTC and may represent intraglandular metastasis or multiple primary tumors

Additionally, cervical lymph node metastasis is common, particularly in children, who may have a 50% incidence of clinically detectable nodal disease at presentation

The primary treatment is surgery. Other mainstays of therapy are radioactive iodine ablation and TSH suppression.

For a patient with unilateral thyroid malignancy and no evidence of metastasis, there are several rationales to consider total thyroidectomy

  • RAI ablation is less effective and requires a larger dosage if residual thyroid exists
  • Occult multifocal disease
  • Facilitating the use of thyroglobulin as a tumor marker

Total thyroidectomy is recommended for all PTCs 1cm or larger in size

PTCs less than 1 cm in diameter are defined as microcarcinoma

Surgery is not required for these patients

  • If there are no clinically involved nodes
  • No extrathyroidal extension
  • No history of head and neck irradiation

In clinically negative central compartment nodes, prophylactic dissection is indicated in higher-risk situations, such as

  • Tumours that are larger than 4 cm
  • Tumours that are gross extrathyroidal extension
  • Tumours with lateral neck nodal disease
